person.persName: THE EMPEROR IN THE STAINED GLASS

front.p: IN GRATEFUL REMEMBRANCE OF RARE INCENTIVES TO THIS WORK

castList.head: CHARACTERS
castList.castItem: PIERRE D'ARC, brother of Jeanne, courting Mengette .
SEIGNEUR PIERRE DE BOURLEMENT, proprietor of "The Ladies' Tree."
GERARD, home from the English wars, betrothed to Hauviette .
GERARDIN, a Burgundian villager, courting Isabellette .
THE "LADIES OF LORRAINE," i.e. the Fairies of the Tree .
SEIGNEUR DE LA TREMOUILLE, his favorite .
REGNAULT DE CHARTRES, Archbishop of Rheims .
RÉNÉ DE BOULIGNY, Receiver-General of France .
JEAN DE METZ, of Jeanne's escort to the King .
BERTRAND DE POULANGY, of the same .
PASQUEREL, St. Augustine Friar, Jeanne's Confessor .
LOUIS DE CONTES, Jeanne's Page, a boy .
CATHERINE DE LA ROCHELLE, Lady of King Charle's Court at Chinon .
DIANE, Lady of King Charle's Court at Chinon .
ATHENIE, Lady of King Charle's Court at Chinon .
THE VOICE OF THE JUDGE'S CLERK.
SERVANTS, POPULACE, PRIESTS, FRIARS, COURTIERS, PEASANTS, SOLDIERS.

set.p: SCENES ACT I "The Ladies' Tree," near Domremy; Springtime, 1428 . ACT II The Castle of King Charles VII, at Chinon; March 8, 1429 . ACT III A meadow outside the Walls of Orleans; the attack on the Tournelles; May 7, 1429 . ACT IV SCENE I. Jeanne's camp before the Walls of Troyes, en route for Rheims; night of July 5, 1429 . SCENE II. A street in Rheims, seen from an old wall of the city; Coronation Pageant of King Charles; Sunday, July 17, 1429 . ACT V Jeanne's prison at Rouen; May 30, 1431 .

div.head: ACT I
div.stage: SCENE: "The Ladies' Tree" near Domremy.

Springtime of 1428; a holiday gathering of young folk from the hamlet . The trunk of the great beech tree, rising toward the back of the scene, left centre, spreads its branches ( left ) to a group of white birches, in the half concealment of which stands a stone bench. From beneath the branches of the beech ( on the right ), one looks away to the outskirts of a little French thatched village, more guessed than seen, in the not-far distance. Almost touching the tree-bole ( on the left ) stands a shrine, with a painted image of the Virgin . Near this, leaning against the tree, sits a young man (GERARD), dressed — in part — as a soldier, one arm and his breast being bandaged. He watches the boys and girls dancing a country round, in which the latter carry garlands. On the edge of the dance ( left ) sits a placid group of old women knitting . The Boys and Girls, taking respective parts in voice and pantomime, sing as they dance .

With a finale of tossed kisses and dropt curtsies, the lasses give their garlands to the lads, who hang them on the trunk of the beech tree, after which all scatter, laughing and talking, into groups — cracking nuts, love-making, playing games. In one group ( right ), playing knuckle-bone on the grass, is JEANNE D'ARC, inconspicuous amongst the others

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Mine hangs too high; they'll have to stand tip-toe
To reach it.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: The Ladies of Lorraine.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: But who —

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Hush, Gerardin; some call them ladies,
Some, fairies; but my granny says that they
Long time ago were queens in old Provence
Who fell in love with their own troubadours,
And so were banished by their jealous kings
Far northward to Lorraine; and here, because
They sorrowed with so piteous melody,
Singing the dear songs of their lovers dead,
They won the fairy's hospitality.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: And so these garlands are for them?

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Of course!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.stage: Dancing before Gerard and hugging him
sp.l: Lon lon, la la, deri dera!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.stage: With a twinge, smiling up at her
sp.l: My arm!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: My poor Gerard! — did she forget his wounds?
Ah, naughty garçon , what's he good for now?
Look, Perrin, how they've hacked my fine sweet boy —
The English fiends!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Burgundians, they were.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: 'Tis six o' one! They've chopped him up so fine
I'm going to serve him on a silver dish
With lettuce hearts and little parsley leaves —
Ragoût Gerard, avec les petites têtes Anglaises .

div.stage: She laughs merrily

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Don't, don't, Hauviette; you know he may not live.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Gerard, sweetheart! I love thee!

div.stage: She weeps

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Little swallow!

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.l: Jeannette is on her knees.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Telling her beads?

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.l: No, playing knucklebone there with the boys.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: She's brought her knitting with her; think of it!

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.l: Colin will get a good wife.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Colin? — Pfui!

sp.speaker: PIERRE D'ARC
sp.stage: Uncovering his face by the tree, shouts
sp.l: Time!

div.stage: Hunts for others who are playing hide-and-seek with him

sp.speaker: TWO GIRLS
sp.l: Asusée! Asusée!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Hauviette —

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: My fine boy must not talk; 'tis bad for him.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: I think —

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: A raisin!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: But —

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: An almond!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: You —

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Crack it!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: I —

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Bite! — a cookie.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Wish —

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: A kiss, then!

div.stage: Kisses him on the mouth

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Heigh, Gerardin! See here — this walnut.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: Hein?

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: This here's the Duke of Burgundy — his skull.

div.stage: Smashes the nut loudly. The others laugh and jeer good-naturedly at Gerardin, whose proffered arm Isabellette taking, sticks out her tongue at them

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Seigneur the Duke hath brains.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.stage: Thrusting a walnut between his jaws
sp.l: I crack 'em — so!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Is he there — ?

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Hush!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Burgundian?

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Now, now,
If you're not quiet —

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Curse him!

sp.speaker: PIERRE D'ARC
sp.stage: Creeping stealthily behind Mengette, claps his hand over her eyes
sp.l: Name me!

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.l: Pierre!
Be still! Here comes the Sieur de Bourlement.

div.stage: General commotion; all who are seated — save Gerard — get to their feet

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.stage: Shrugs defiantly and makes a face off right
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: My dear, he owns the Ladies' Tree, and half
The land of Domremy.

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMEN
sp.l: Seigneur de Bourlement!

div.stage: Enter, right , DE BOURLEMENT. He strolls in dreamily; in one hand a book; in the other, a walking-stick, which he twirls

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: Good-morrow, dears, good-morrow.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Save Seigneur!

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.stage: After a pause, during which he reads
sp.l: Now, now, my pretties, do not stand and stare.
And why are not you dancing? When I saw
You lassies twinkling on the grass, methought
The little marguerites had learned to run.

div.stage: Twirling his cane he drops it. Jeanne springs forward and lifts it

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Seigneur — your walking-stick.

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: My wand, Jeannette!
This is the month of May and I am Merlin.
Ask what you will, my lads: 'tis granted you.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: I want Jeannette.

div.stage: The others giggle

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: I grant thee, swain — to want her.
Love, Springtime, laughter — c'est la poesie!

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Nay —

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: Smell, boy! Smell this day! and mark what myth
Still lurks i' the nostril: 'tis a charmèd grotto
Where sleeps a nymph, to whom a thousand flowers
Make odorous minstrelsy; and for her love
The tender lyric of the fleur-de-lys,
The blue-bell's clear chanson , the daisy's ballad,
Yea, and the languorous rondel of the rose —

Are all respired. —
[ Bowing .]
Encore la poesie!

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: I want to wed her.

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: Shepherd, hast thou never
Taken a little walk toward sunset time
Along the fields? One pauses now and then
To squint the lids, and watch against the west
The cowslip-colour'd light steam from the flocks
To float in haloes 'gainst the quiet clouds;
One sniffs the spearmint by the river's brink,
And waits for dusk-fall, and the twittering
Of swallows overhead, and underneath
The nibbling sound of half-distinguished sheep,
The neatherd's whistle and the colley's bark,
The vesper bell, and with that — voices of angels.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Amen!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.stage: Who has heard de Bourlement with impatient scorn, tries to rise
sp.l: And what of France, Seigneur?

div.stage: Hauviette, frightened, claps her hand over his mouth

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: In France
The dew that fills the lily's cup is song.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Song cannot make us men in France, Seigneur,
Nor drive the English bloodhounds from our homes.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Pardon! Oh, sir, he's very ill.

sp.speaker: DE BOURLEMENT
sp.l: Poor boy!
I wish him better. Come, my dears. To-day
Is Sunday of the Wells. Let see which one
Shall win the foot-race to the holy well.

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG FOLK
sp.l: The race! Outré!

div.stage: They crowd about de Bourlement .]

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Come to the starting line.

div.stage: Preceded by de Bourlement with his cane, and followed in the rear by the old knitting-women, exeunt behind the birches all but Gerard and Hauviette

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.stage: Gloomily, as Hauviette bends over him
sp.l: Fly with them, bonny swallow; don't wait here
Beating your slender wings about my eyes.
You cannot blind me, dear; I see it well
That I am through with life.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Tu-whit! to-whoo!
His bonny swallow will peck out those eyes,
If they stare so.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Nay, leave!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: I will not hop
One inch from him.

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.l: Outré!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Ah, hear them now!
'Tis the beginning.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: And the ending.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.stage: Running to the edge of the scene
sp.l: Oh!
Pierre d'Arc has stuck a rose in Mengette's hair.
She pulled it out, but he has put it back.
Now they've all toed the line; there's five of 'em:
Perrin, Mengette, Pierre d'Arc, Jeannette, and Colin.
Jeannette's between her brother and her sweetheart.

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.l: Make ready!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: That's the Sieur de Bourlement. — Listen!

sp.speaker: THE VOICE
sp.l: Prepare! — Depart!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.stage: Rushing back to the edge of scene
Hauviette holds herself tensely with clenched hands. From outside there come shouts of "Perrin! Pierre! Jeannette!" etc., presently, in the distance, sounding only one name , " Jeannette ."]
sp.l: Now! Now they're off!
Run! Run!

Perrin's ahead. — Ha! — Now! —
[ Shouts ]
— Jeannette! Jeannette!
Jeannette is winding him. — Faster, Jeannette!
Ah, now they're hid behind the willows. — Peste!
I cannot see.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Run after them.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: I won't!
Sacré Maria! Hark! Jeannette — she's won!
Thou wretched boy! Why ever did you fight
Those English ogres? Now thou art a stump;
Can't race, can't dance, can't play. O saints! to have
A sweetheart half i' the grave! — Darling Gerard,
Forgive her! Please forgive her!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.stage: Caressing her, where she snuggles close to him

While Gerard and Hauviette are absorbed in each other thus, boughs of the shrubbery part noiselessly, and Jeanne breaks upon the scene, panting and flushed from running. Not seeing the lovers beneath the beech tree, she seats herself on the stone bench, braids her hair, which has flown loose in the race, takes out her knitting, but lets it fall beside her, fixing her eyes dreamily on the air. Gerard meantime has been playfully humming to Hauviette
Hauviette, spying Jeanne, turns Gerard's head and points. Voices in the distance call "Jeannette!"
sp.l: There, there, there!
My sweetheart's a swallow:
Her sprite's
On wing;
Oh, might I follow
Her flights,
I'd bring
Back from Heaven the heart of Spring.
Jeannette! — What is she doing?

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Hiding from 'em;
Always she's stealing off alone.
They say
She talks with God.
Let's ask her.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Don't!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Hallo!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Ha! bon gré Dieu!
No one but thee, Hauviette?

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Me and Gerard. — What made you leave the race?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: 'Twas finished.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: But you won the prize.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Just that!
The Jack-o'-ninnies fetched a crown of laurel

To set upon my head.
[ Laughing .]
Ha! but St. John!
I cut away into the underwood
And put 'em off my track.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.stage: Seeing Isabellette appear through the birches
sp.l: Look sharp, then.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Found!

sp.speaker: GERARDIN'S VOICE
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Here.
But hush!
We must not spoil
Mamselle's devotions.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.stage: Making a mock bow to Jeanne .]
sp.l: Pray, Mamselle, forgive
My rude intrusion.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Nay, you're welcome, sir.
God puts a sweet root in the little pig's path,
So we're well met.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: Hein? Am I root or pig?

div.stage: Enter Colin with a wreath of green leaves

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Here is thy crown, Jeannette.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Pish! not that one!
Run to the window of the kirk, and fetch
Yon little halo made of painted glass —
Sky-blue and gold; she left it by mistake
Last time she prayed there.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Run, thou dunderhead!
How shall we get to Heaven without Jeannette?

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Yon keys, that dangle at her waist, unlock
St. Peter's wicket.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Na; I will not go.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: I dare you steal 'em.

div.stage: Makes a dash at Jeanne's keys .]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Catching Hauviette's hand powerfully with her left, laughs
Snatching at their faces with her right hand, she criss-crosses the thumb, child-fashion .]
sp.l: If you poke more fun
I'll have your noses all! One, two, three, four!
Now you'll not hold 'em in the air so high.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Wicked Jeannette! She won't be teased.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: But tell!
What made you run away alone?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: To listen.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Listen! — for what?

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: What did you hear?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Let's go.

div.stage: As she moves away, the others exchange nods and shrugs

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Eh! what said I — 'twas them! They be her friends
And keep her company.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Who are my friends?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: The lady wood-folk: I ha' seen 'em with 'ee
Many's the chance at sundown.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Seen them with her?

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: What — speaking?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Like as though.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: At sundown?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Darkish.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Here, beside their tree.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Thou art wrong, Colin.
'Tis well to know that since the good priest read
The gospel of St. John beneath these boughs,
There are no fairies more in Domremy.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: O pfui!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: You don't believe? — But Colin saw!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Saw moonshine! — I believe my own good eyes
And ears. I never saw nor heard them.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Eh!
Thy father saith how folk what's spoken to
By fairies knoweth naught of it; but getteth
Gifties most wonderful.

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.l: Aha! That's why
He wants to marry thee, Jeannette.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Aye, that's!

div.stage: Voices shout outside, amidst laughter .]

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: Hark there! Come on! We're missing all the game.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Ah me! if only I could go!

sp.speaker: ISABELLETTE
sp.stage: Pulling Hauviette's sleeve as she passes
sp.l: Come, too!

div.stage: Exit
As Gerardin is hastening out, Gerard — with a great effort — lifting his sword in its scabbard, flings it clattering in front of Gerardin, who starts back

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Burgundian!

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: You dropt this sword?

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: I flung it
In challenge, sir.

sp.speaker: GERARDIN
sp.l: Bah! I'm no corpse-killer.

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Stupid Gerard!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Fetch him some water; go.
I'll stay with him.

div.stage: Voices shout outside

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: I'm coming!
Silly boy!

div.stage: Pulling Colin after her, exit Hauviette. Jeanne, lifting Gerard's sword reverently, places it by the tree

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: My sword — your lips have touched it!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: God himself
Hath fought with it for France.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: I fought with it!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: And God did clasp His fingers over thine
Along the hilt. Whoso hath fought for France
Hath fought for Him.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Jeannette! you knew, then, why
I flung it there! You knew?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Full well, my friend.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: None other knew.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: None here besides hath been
Into the battle.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Never you have been.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Ah me, Gerard, so often have I gone
Amongst the armèd men, methinks I scarce
Have stayed at home.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: You saw the fighting? When?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Between the shearing and the shearing.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Out there — beyond: in the wide land beyond!
And there were thousands flashing in the sun
Beneath dark walls and mighty battlements,
And all their shining limbs were stiff with steel;
And rank by rank they rattled as they marched,
But each half hid his neighbour with his shield
Like soldiers in the chapel-window glass;
And I rode with them, clad in silver mail
From heel to head, upon a snow-white horse,
And all my oriflammes were painted fair
With lilies and the Rising of our Lord;
For we were marching, midst the roar of bells,
Towards a great cathedral.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: But you dreamed!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Once in the midnight, when I saw them sleeping
After the battle, in the still moonshine
Their linkèd armour lay beside them, sloughed
Like adder skins; and where the living slept,
Their bright breaths rose like candle mist, but on
The dead the dews fell.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: How saw you these sights?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Sometimes I see them very small and bright,
As if they were inlaid in smooth enamel
Like wish-stones in my godfather's thumb-ring.
Sometimes I gaze at them as through clear water,
That moves between us, blurring the deep colours
With skeins of silver when the wind blows. Ah!
But tell me of the wars which you have seen.
I have great pity for the land of France.
Tell me — for you have fought — what of the wars?

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.l: Vivo la roso!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Will you not go — play?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Adjusting his cloak as a back rest
sp.l: Now think ye they are sighing for me?
Move
A little; so is better?

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: It is better.
You asked — what of the wars?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Thou art still in pain.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Not now; my body's pain is strangely numb, —
What of the wars? Thou knowest the bitter news:
The English are flooded up like the North Sea
Over the fields of France, where all the land
Southward to Orleans drowns with them, and all
The men of France, like moles and field-mice, creep
Under the bloodied furrows.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Orleans stands!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Yes; stands like a strong headland in their tide
And will not crumble. Orleans only stands
Between the English army and King Charles.
Yet soon must also Orleans fall, and then —
What hope then for the King?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: God fights for him.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: They say that he is poor and hath few friends,
And daily those desert him, taunting him
That he hath never been crowned.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: He shall be crowned.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: And Burgundy the Duke, the one strong man
Whose right arm should have struck for France, now fights
For England and the taste of English gold. —
O God! Jeannette, if thou hadst fought for France,
Now mightest thou feel what 'tis of bitterness
To close my eyes and go down in the dark,
Knowing that even this dust of me must change
Into a little heap of English earth.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Gerard! — and you must die?

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Last night, the doctor
Went from my door to Jacques-the-gravedigger's;
To-day they fetched me here with garlands.

div.stage: Rising slowly to her feet, Jeanne holds in her left hand Gerard's sword, and raising her right as one taking a martial oath, speaks with dreamy fervour

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Listen!
Between Coussy and Vaucouleurs there lives
A girl, that, ere the year is gone, shall save
The land of France, and consecrate King Charles.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: A girl! — between Coussy and Vaucouleurs?
That's here in Domremy.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Have you not heard
How long ago 'twas spoken, "Out of Lorraine,
Beside the Ladies' Tree, shall come a maid —
Saviour of France"?

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: This is the Ladies' Tree!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: And truly was it spoken. — I am the Maid.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Jeannette!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: It hath been told me.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Who hath told?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The Lord hath sent His angel, even St. Michael,
To me, Jeannette.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Thou hast beheld him?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: And heard him speak?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Often.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: When was this?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: First
Four years ago. 'Twas in my father's garden;
I was then but thirteen; I heard his voice.
It was mid-day, in summer; I was frightened.
I had not fasted on the day before.
A little to my right, towards the church,
I heard it; on one side there shone a light.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: What! — in the noon time?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Yes; a burning light.
It dazzled me; and then I saw his face.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Alone?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: It was surrounded all with angels,
That glittered like the little poplar leaves
Behind our barn.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: You saw them bodily?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I saw them with these eyes as clearly as
I see you there. Just then the mass bell rung,
And then St. Michael spoke.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Mind you what words?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: He said: "Jeanne d'Arc, thy Lord hath chosen thee
To save the land of France. When I am gone,
St. Catherine will come and Margaret,
His saints, to counsel thee."

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: More did he say?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: "Be good and wait," he said; and then once more
"Be a good girl, Jeannette," he said; and so
He and his angels went away, and I
Wept, for I would have liked to go with them.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: St. Catherine and Margaret — they came?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Often they come.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: You have seen them also?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Yes;
But oftenest I hear them speak; I call them
"My Voices," and I hear them when the bells
Are ringing — more at Matins and at Vespers
Than other hours. At first they counselled me
But to be good, and to prepare myself
Against St. Michael's coming. But of late
They have forewarned me I must go to raise
The siege ofOrleans and have crowned the Dauphin.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: For what, then, dost thou wait, Jeannette?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: St. Michael,
His coming.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Ah! and will he come again
Before — I go?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My Voices warn me oft
That he at any moment may appear
And bid me go unto Chinon, the Castle
Of Charles the Dauphin, and make known to him
My mission from our Lord.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: He will believe!
Jeannette, he will believe, as I! — O France,
Out of Lorraine hath come the Lord His maid
To succour thee in thy death peril!

sp.speaker: JACQUES D'ARC
sp.l: Colin!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My father! Tell him not. I have not leave
To tell yet what I know. You I have told,
For you must soon go hence before my saints,
And will explain my trespass.

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: I will tell them
How you revealed their secret to one dead
And made him happy.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: He would grieve, besides,
And rage, and would not let me leave him.
Hush!

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Round up the sheep with me.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Where keepst thy dog?

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Suckleth her whelps at home. Hark yonder! Yon's
The bell-wether, hath jumped the pound. — Good e'en,
Jeannette. Aye, knitting, hein?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: God give good e'en.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: What for not making holiday? 'Tis Sabbath;
Seigneur himself walks yon with the young folk;
And Colin there clapt to 't with another sweetheart, —
Ah, Colin?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.stage: Jerking his thumb at Jeanne and Gerard
sp.l: She would browse with the lame sheep.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: What for with him?

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: She asked me of the wars.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: The wars? Hark here, lass. Drop that gabble; drop 't,
I warn thee, down the nighest well and bury 't.
No maid o' mine shall gossip o' the wars
With any man. — And hast forgot my dream,
Jeannette?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Ofttime dreams be perilous.
I saw thee in my dream fighting for France,
And thou wert bleeding at the breast. May God
Forgi'e 't me! — Ere thou went to war, Jeannette,
I'd have thy brothers drown thee.
Where's thy staff?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Over against the sheep-pound.

div.stage: There run in Hauviette, Mengette, Pierre, Ferrin, and Others

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Fetch Gerard!

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Come! — Wait for me, Jeannette; we'll home with 'ee.

div.stage: Exeunt Jacques and Colin right .]

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: Gerard, Gerard, three kisses! Then up, up!

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Where is the swallow flying!

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: With the flock
Of course.

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.l: You're coming with us?

sp.speaker: PIERRE
sp.l: To be cured.

sp.speaker: HAUVIETTE
sp.l: We're going to the well of thorns; Seigneur
Is waiting for us. 'Tis a sacred well,
And filled with holy water to the brim;
And when you drink of it, you will be cured.

sp.speaker: PIERRE
sp.l: Make him a chair.

sp.speaker: SEVERAL OTHERS
sp.l: A chair!

div.stage: Pierre and another lad by interlacing their hands form a seat into which Gerard is raised

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Now up with him!

div.stage: Lifted by the two lads, Gerard is carried off, surrounded by the others shouting

sp.speaker: GERARD
sp.l: Good-by, Jeannette; I'm going to be cured.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Adieu, Gerard!

sp.speaker: THE OTHERS
sp.l: Outré! Gerard! Gerard!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: To Perrin, as he is leaving with the others
sp.l: Perrin!

div.stage: Perrin pauses and looks at Jeanne, who shakes her finger at him with a grave smile. He drops his eyes, confused

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: But 'tisn't late.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The sky's all pink
And gold behind the bell-tower.
Naughty Perrin!
What will Our Lady say, who leaneth there
And listeneth for her Vesper bell, and heareth
Perrin at play.

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: I cannot ring just yet.
The others —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Thrusting her knitting into his hands
sp.l: Here's a mitten; 'tis of wool.
I'll knit thee its fellow before Michaelmas
If thou wilt run fast to the kirk, and ring
The bell.

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Our Lady shall not scold, then. — Mind,
Thou'lt knit me t'other mitten?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I have promised.

div.stage: Perrin runs off toward Domremy. Jeanne, going slowly to the Ladies' Tree, leans against the trunk, and stands looking westward toward the town. As she does so, there rises — faint but close by, through the falling twilight — a music of sweet voices, singing to the old French ballad-melody these words, softly distinguishable

sp.speaker: THE TWILIGHT VOICES
sp.l: Derrièr' chez mon père,
(Vole, vole, mon coeur vole!)
Derrièr' chez mon père
Y'a un pommier doux:
Tout doux — et iou!
Tout doux — et iou!
Y'a un pommier doux.
Trois belles princesses
(Vole, vole, mon coeur, vole!)
Trois belles princesses
Sont assis dessous:
Tout doux — et iou!
Tout doux — et iou!
Sont assis dessous.
Ça dit la première, vole, etc.
Je crois qu'il fait jour.
Ça dit la seconde — etc.
J'entends le tambour.

div.stage: Jeanne, pensive, does not hear the melody, nor observe how near her, from amid the obscurity of the birch trees, there emerge the shadowy forms of the LADIES OF LORRAINE. Each of these peers forth from her own bush or birch or flowering shrub, to which her garb — with its long green veil and flowing forest gown — approximates in tone and design. [Footnote: 1Kb Thus the veil of the Lady of the Flowering Thorn is embroidered all with thorn blossoms; the gown of the Lady of the Aspen twinkles and shivers with little leaves. Each wears a crown and has an air at once queenly and sylvan

sp.speaker: THE LADIES OF LORRAINE
sp.l: Ça dit la troisième — etc.
C'est mon ami doux.
Il va-t-a la guerre — etc.
Combattre pour nous.

div.stage: Ceasing, none of the Ladies entirely dissociates herself from her bush or tree, but peering forward, all together, they lift from their brows, and hold aloft with their right hands, their crowns and fillets and therewith lay a spell upon Jeanne, who — outwardly oblivious of their presence — yet is felt to soliloquize under their influence, not beginning to speak until they appear, and ceasing simultaneous with their abrupt departure .]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: How happily doth all the world go home!
The bee hath left the shutting marguerite
To dust his wings at Pierrot's garden-door
And hum all night to drowsy chanticleer;
The rooks are whirling to the nested eaves. —
Thou little darling town of Domremy,
Good night! Thou winkest with thy lids of vines,
And layest down within the golden stream
Thy yellow thatches and thy poplars pale;
And thou, too, art upgathered in home-fields;
But thy Jeannette must pass away from thee.
For He who once disdainèd not to stay
His wandering star o'er tiny Bethlehem
Hath, in His love of France, sent unto thee
His shining messengers to fetch thy Maid.
O little town, hush still thy breath and hark!
Amid thy narrow streets are angels arming,
And o'er thy steeping-stones immortal feet
Are bearing light the undying fleur-de-lis;
And from thy roofs clear horns-of-Paradise
Are blowing wide unto the zenith: Hearken! —
Who shall withstand the Lord of Hosts, or who
Defy His power? The horses of the Lord
Are neighing, terrible; His chariots
Of thunder crash in darkness, and the voice
Calleth of His Archangel from the battle:
"Vive la France! Victoire! La France sauvée!"

sp.speaker: JACQUES D'ARC
sp.stage: The Ladies vanish in the foliage. Jeanne stands as in a trance. Enter right Jacques, grasping by the wrist Colin, who holds back, quaking
sp.l: Along! Along!
Where be they? Show me where?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Na, na; I'll not come nigh her. They be gone Inside.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Inside o' what?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: The bark and roots:
I saw them yonder lifting o' their veils.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Where?
Those be birches.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Ladies were they then,
And peered and peeped at her.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: At who?

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Jeannette;
I'll not come nigh her.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.stage: Visibly affected, yet will not show it to Colin
sp.l: Pfah! Thou hast such visions
As Pertelote, our hen: spyeth the moon,
And cackleth she hath laid our Lord an egg. —
Jeannette o' mine, come hither.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Breaking from her revery, goes impetuously to his arms
sp.l: Papa Jacques!

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.stage: Embracing her tenderly, looks toward the birches
sp.l: Th' art a good lass, Jeannette. I spake thee harsh
Awhile since.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Will I scold thee for it now?

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: A good lass was thou always; — but some stubborn.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Like Papa Jacques?

div.stage: Kisses him

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Aye, Jacques d'Arc hath a will.
Th' art come short-cut thereby! But hark'ee, girl!
Shut mouth catches no flies. — I'll have thee speak
No more o' the wars. — What say? I'll have thee be
Like other village maid-folk — light o' heart,
Merry to love. — Eh, not? — I'll have thee wed,
And keep thy goodman's sheep-farm next to mine.
Come now: What say to Colin?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: 'Tis a good lad.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: St. John! 'Tis a good answer. Once again!
What say to speak him troth now — man and maid?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I may not speak my troth to any man.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: May not! May not! Who's thy new master, sith
Thy father died? Who hath forbade thee speak?
Well, well; let be! Thou needst not speak thy troth.
Look: yonder, Colin holds his sheep-staff out
Toward thee; take it, lass, and nothing spoke —
In token of thy trothal.

div.stage: Jeanne, gazing apparently at Colin, clasps suddenly her hands in awe, and makes a humble reverence .]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Monseigneur!
Thy maid is ready.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Take 't and come along.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: What is that which you see held forth to me?

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Seest well thyself 'tis Colin's staff. What for
Art staring?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: 'Tis exceeding beautiful
In glory and in power; its handle gleams
Bright as the cross of jewels at the mass,
And oh, its sheath is like an altar-candle.

div.stage: In the distance a bell begins to ring slowly. Jacques bows his head. Colin, awed by Jeanne's words and expression, thrusts the staff upright in the earth and steps back a pace from it, superstitiously

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: The Vespers.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Monseigneur!

div.stage: At this moment in the air beside Colin appears the glorified form of ST. MICHAEL. Shepherd and Archangel stand contrasted, yet alike in posture, looking toward Jeanne

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Up, lass! What aileth?
Wilt take the sheep-crook?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Wilt thou have me take
What in the turf stands yonder?

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: In God's name!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: In God's name, then, I take it.

div.stage: Reaching out, she pauses and draws back — her face lifted to St. Michael's — as, in the cadence of the bell, he speaks

sp.speaker: ST. MICHAEL
sp.stage: Lightly laying his hand upon the staff, instantaneously his touch transforms it to a perpendicular sword, its point piercing the turf, its cross-formed handle and its sheath glowing with variegated fire
sp.l: Jeanne the Maid,
Behold the staff I bring thee is my sword.
Take it in vow of thy virginity,
And to perform the bidding of thy Lord —
That thou, in armour girded as a man
Shalt go to raise at Orleans the great siege,
And after, crown the Dauphin, Charles of France,
Anointed King at Rheims.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: The crook, Jeannette!
Take it in troth.

sp.speaker: ST. MICHAEL
sp.l: Take it in troth, Jeanne d'Arc.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: In God His name, I take it as from Him
To whom my vow is given.

div.stage: Extending her hand, Jeanne touches the sword; then bows her head as St. Michael disappears

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: So; she hath touched
Thy staff in trothal, lad. Now home with ye
Together.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Come, Jeannette.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: First, I will pray.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: The Vespers! — Come along. — She'll follow us.

sp.speaker: COLIN
sp.l: Sith for Charity
My love her troth me gave,
My troth hath she
I her have.

div.stage: Exit Colin. Jacques, looking back at Jeanne, crosses himself, muttering, and exit. Twilight deepens. Blending with the tones of the chapel bell are heard two Voices .]

sp.speaker: THE FIRST VOICE
sp.l: Jeanne d'Arc!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: St. Margaret!

sp.speaker: THE SECOND VOICE
sp.l: Jeanne la Pucelle!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: St. Catherine!

sp.speaker: THE TWO VOICES
sp.l: Daughter of God, go forth!

div.stage: Jeanne, on the turf, kneels before the cross of the shining sword. Vespers continue to ring

div.head: ACT II
div.stage: SCENE: The Castle of Chinon. March 8, 1429.

An audience-hall, sparsely furnished with an indigent magnificence . The chief entrance at back is in the centre. On the right of this an ornate clock, with chimes. On the left, high in the wall, a stained-glass window depicts the Emperor Charlemagne, with the shield of France, holding a crown. Against the left wall, a throne-chair with canopy; in the right wall, a fireplace with chimney-seat. At the oblique angle of the right and back walls, a stairway descends from a colonnade, partly visible without . The scene, opening, discovers KING CHARLES seated on an arm of the throne-chair, with one foot on the seat, the other crossed over his knee. Round his neck, behind, is hung a placard, lettered in red and gold: LE ROI DAGOBERT C'EST MOI He is surrounded by LADIES of the Court, who are merrily shouting a song, whilst they watch the royal TAILOR, who bends assiduously over the King's crossed leg, plying his thread and needle. Beside him stands his spool-and-shears basket . Apart from these, at a table near the fire, are seated LA TREMOUILLE and DE CHARTRES. The former is busily engaged in looking over a pile of parchments. From time to time he is approached with great reverence by servants and courtiers .

sp.speaker: THE LADIES
sp.l: 'Twas good King Dagobert
His breeches wrong-side-out did wear.
Quoth his Master of Stitches:
"Your Majesty's breeches,
To put it mild strongly,
Are put on well wrongly."
"Eh bien!" the King he cried,
"Just wait and I'll turn 'em right side."

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: This seal to the Receiver-General;
These parchments to the Treasurer of War.

sp.speaker: THE LADIES
sp.l: God save King Dagobert!

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Good Majesty
Doth wear the seam outside.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Why not, old Stitches?
I'll set the fashion so; I am chafed too long
With wearing o' the seamy-side within .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Still munching the old cud of melancholy —
His mother.

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.l: Why his mother?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Shh! They say
She called him —

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.l: Hein?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: They spell it with a "b."

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: Imperial Dagobert, permit thy slave
To be thy needle-woman.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Nay, let me;
My silk is threaded.

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.l: 'Twere a thousand pities
To wholly sheathe so glorious a sword!
Is it of gold?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Ah, lady, would it were,
And I would lend it out at usury
To line your purse withal. — Alas, madame,
'Tis a poor limb charr'd with celestial fire.

div.stage: Waves her back

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Ladies, we may not look. We must content
Our souls with incense of the burning thigh.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.stage: To La Tremouille, amid the Ladies' laughter
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: They are his only pair;
The rest he pawned this morning. These being torn,
He calls the tailor and commands the ladies
To acclaim him as King Dagobert.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: What for?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: For novelty. One day he'll hang himself
For novelty.

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Your Majesty is mended.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Approach, mesdames, and view the royal patch.

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: But where?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: I cannot see it.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Even so!
Your patch is virtue's own epitome,
The smooth'd-up leak in honour's water-mark,
The small fig-leaf that shadows Paradise,
The tiny seal of time and turpitude.
Which for to prove, sweet dames, bethink you how
The great Achilles — he who fought and sulked
Outside the walls of Troy — was once a babe,
(Babes will occur, mesdames!) and had a mother
(The best of us have mothers, though not all
Be goddesses). His mother was called Thetis,
And when she dipped him in the immortal wave,
She held him by the heel — thus — thumb and finger,
That ever afterward upon the heel
He wore a patch — a little viewless patch,
Whereby he came to dust. The moral's plain:
A little patch is greater than a god,
And therefore this your prince, poor Dagobert,
Doth kiss his hands to you and abdicate
In lieu of one more royal lord — King Patch.
Acclaim him!

div.stage: Stepping down, Charles mounts the Tailor upon the throne, on the seat of which he stands, in alarmed confusion

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Majesty! — Sweet ladies!

sp.speaker: THE LADIES
sp.l: Hail!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Behold the man who mendeth Alexander,
And ravelleth up the rended Cæsar's wounds:
Lo! moth corrupteth us, and mildew stains,
Diana frays her moon-white taffeta,
Yea, Phoebus sullieth his golden hose,
Fate makes or mars us, but King Patch doth mend!

sp.speaker: BOULIGNY
sp.stage: Having just entered, claps his palm
sp.l: Par excellence, a Cicero!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Your servant,
Bouligny! — now to crown him, ladies.

sp.speaker: THE LADIES
sp.l: Crown him!

div.stage: Catherine snatches up the work-basket and, inverting, lifts it — dangling with spools, bobbins, and shears — toward the Tailor

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Dames! Gentle dames!

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.stage: Thrusting the basket over his head
sp.l: A crown!

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.stage: Forcing a yardstick into his hand
sp.l: A sceptre!

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Virgin!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Long live King Patch!

div.stage: The Tailor, extricating himself, giggling and grinning a scared smile, bobs and kisses his palm to Charles and the Ladies, who shout with laughter

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Pardon and compliments!
Pardon, mesdames, seigneurs, and compliments!

div.stage: At the height of this royal mockery, there enters from the colonnade , D'ALENÇON — a quiet, contrasting figure. He is scribbling on a parchment and pauses. Glancing from the throne-chair scene, he turns to where La Tremouille and De Chartres are talking together apart, and silently approaches them

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Behold the King of France enthroned.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: You mean
That we must strive to keep him thus.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: I mean
That he who holds a mortgage on a king
May keep the sceptre for security
During the debt's outstanding.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: How the sceptre?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: The power, De Chartres; like yonder Knave of Spools
Charles wields the royal yardstick, but the King
Of France — the man that reigns — c'est moi!

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: And I?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: Suddenly; over his shoulder observing D'Alençon
sp.l: My privy council.
Ah, D'Alençon! —
Poeticizing?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Yes; I am composing
A rondel on the weather, called " It rains ."

div.stage: De Chartres and La Tremouille glance at each other quizzically. With a studious look D'Alençon turns away, and takes from the fireplace a book

sp.speaker: THE COURT LADIES
sp.l: A speech! A coronation speech!

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Mesdames,
Seigneurs, and compliments! If Majesty
Would pay to me my wage, and let me go.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Thy wage, par dieu! O heart of emery!
Sharpen your needles in him, ladies. Wage!
Wage for a patch!

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Nay, Majesty, a year —
One year, last Candlemas, 'tis overdue.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Hark to the bobbin buzz! What, take thy wages!
Wilt bear 'em on thy back? A twelvemonth, here!
One month — two — three — four!

div.stage: Snatching from him the yardstick, Charles thwacks the Tailor down from the throne, whence he runs, pursued by the Ladies, who prick his sides with their needles

sp.speaker: THE TAILOR
sp.l: Charity, mesdames!

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: Pauses, laughing, and greets D'Alençon, who, over his book, has been looking keenly on
sp.l: What think you of our royal sport, D'Alençon?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: No king, sire, could more quaintly lose his kingdom.

div.stage: Charles, ceasing his laughter with a conscious look, vaguely ashamed, hesitates, then follows D'Alençon, who has turned away, and — walking aside with him — grows strangely serious

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Behold my Rome and Rubicon.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: What — yonder?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: That man is in my way; he must be crossed
Before the King is mine.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: That bookworm duke!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: His influence grows.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Nay, hardly with the King!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: De Chartres, you know not Charles; he's like a tree-frog
That takes the colour of the bark it clings to.
Watch how demure he holds the young duke's sleeve
And alters to the dim scholastic hue
Of vellum and antique philosophy;
As quickly would he turn blood-colour, if
The duke should flush with feeling.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Feeling! Flush?
Why, 'tis a rhyming clerk! — a duke of parchment!
The mere illumination of a man
Stuck in life's margin to adorn the text.
He feels for naught this side the Fall of Troy.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: You have forgot "It rains"?

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: A foolish pun!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: About myself: that theme, at least, is new
Since Troy fell. No; I do not trust him. — You
Were best to interrupt their tête-à-tête.

sp.speaker: VENDÔME
sp.stage: At the door, announces to Charles
sp.l: His Majesty's bootmaker!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Show him here.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.stage: As Charles turns momentarily toward Vendôme, touches D'Alençon's volume and speaks to him
sp.l: Who wrote the book?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Pierre Lombard, pupil once
Of Abelard, who sang to Heloise.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Is it godly?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: That your reverence may judge:
The writer plucks a hair out of his head,
Splits it in two, and names the one half Faith
The other, Heresy. The first he dyes
Pure gold, the other pitch-black, and both he nails
As index-fingers on the Church's apse,
And points one hair toward Heaven, the other — elsewhere.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: I do not comprehend.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: Closing the book with a dry smile
sp.l: Neither do I!

div.stage: Exit D'Alençon, right

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: To De Chartres, who returns pensively to him
sp.l: What think you now?

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: I think he thinks too much.

div.stage: Enter the BOOTMAKER, a big raw fellow, in leather. He takes a pair of boots from his apron

sp.speaker: BOOTMAKER
sp.l: Complete, sire.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Let me see them.
Catherine,
What say you to the cut?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Perfection, Charles!
Your Majesty shall walk like Puss-in-Boots
When he proclaimed the Marquis of Carabbas.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: With sudden ennui, comparing the boot with his lower leg
sp.l: Perchance 'twill serve to hide Achilles' heel?
Show me the mate.

sp.speaker: BOOTMAKER
sp.l: Six livres, twenty sous.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: The mate, I said.

sp.speaker: BOOTMAKER
sp.stage: Stolidly, thrusting the mate under his arm
sp.l: Six livres, twenty sous.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Ah? Charge it on account. I'll take the pair.

sp.speaker: BOOTMAKER
sp.l: A bird in the hand makes supper in the pot.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: God's death! Am I the King? Set down the boot
And go!

sp.speaker: BOOTMAKER
sp.stage: Backing to the door, stands sullenly, swinging the one boot by its straps .]
sp.l: Six livres, twenty sous.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: Hurling the other boot after him
sp.l: Go dun
The devil for it!

sp.speaker: BOOTMAKER
sp.stage: Picking up the boot, eyes it over, spits on his apron, and with that rubs the toe of the boot carefully
sp.l: Five and twenty sous!

div.stage: Exit slowly, a boot in each hand. Charles, having watched him go, turns in a pet of frenzy and, flinging down upon the throne footstool, speaks hoarsely to himself, weeping .]

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Am I the King? God, God! Am I the King?

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Have you no smiles for this?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: 'Tis too familiar.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: The little King of Chinon hath caught the sulks,
Sieur La Tremouille.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: I'm busy.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Pardon —
— Sire?

div.stage: La Tremouille smiles slightly and looks down again at his papers. As De Chartres, however, leaves the table to speak with Bouligny, La Tremouille calls Catherine with his eyes, and speaks to her intimately, watching with her the King and smiling

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: Marshal, hast heard what ails the King's game-cocks?

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: No, dame.

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.stage: Flaps her sleeves like a cock's wings
sp.l: 'Tis said that they have shed their spurs,
And strut amongst the hens i' the castle-yard
Crying: "King Noodle-Nothing-Do! Chez nous! "

div.stage: La Hire turns away with a grimace .]

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.l: No wonder the King's figure is god-like.
They say his lady mother had a steward
Shaped like Apollo.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Ladies, I have the ear-ache.

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.l: Beseech you, sire, what may we do to soothe it?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Bring here those honey-flasks of calumny
And pour them in my ears. Perchance 'twill stop
This piping noise within.

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: What piping noise,
Your Majesty?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: A lute within my head:
A slender lute carven with fleur-de-lis,
And at the tip a crown of fleur-de-lis,
And on the stops a lady's fingers lying,
And on the mouth-piece are a lady's lips,
And when they breathe, there opes a tiny rift
Within the fibre, and the hollow thing
Pipes a shrill hellish whistle —
A mere rift,
A little, little rent! —

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Nine thousand francs!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: With a side smile at Catherine
sp.l: The "little rent" you owe me, Charles.
A trifle, as you say, and soon patched up.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: My George! Thou hast a heart of gold! — But you
Must reimburse yourself o' the treasury.
Bouligny!

sp.speaker: BOULIGNY
sp.l: Sire!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: How much in the general fund?

sp.speaker: BOULIGNY
sp.l: Eleven francs, five sous, your Majesty.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Saint dieu! no more than that?

sp.speaker: BOULIGNY
sp.l: Sieur La Tremouille
Hath authorized to-day another loan
From his estates.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: My dear, thou art mine angel!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Tut, Charlie! Go and play.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Nay, by my honour,
But you shall reap your master's gratitude.
When we have raised our arm imperial
And flogged with steel these spindling English —

div.stage: The room bursts into a titter; Charles pauses disconcerted. La Tremouille, badly concealing a smile, raises an admonishing forefinger to the Ladies, who burst into louder laughter. Charles, covering his face, turns precipitately and is rushing from the room when, in the doorway ( back ) he encounters D'Alençon, entering. The latter has evidently just been concerned with the frayed edges of his scroll of parchment, but now — taking in the situation at a glance — he bows to the King with simple reverence

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Sire,
You are generous to cover my confusion.
Yet if these gentles choose to laugh at me —

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: At you!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Why, they are right. You spoke of war,
Of frays where brave men break their limbs and lances,
When lo! — I enter, mending of a parchment.
Should not they laugh? 'Tis such as I, my King,
Such dog-eared captains skulking in their books,
Such Frenchmen, idling in satiric ease
While France lies struck and bleeding — such who bring
Your Majesty's dear reign dishonour. Thanks,
Friends of Chinon! Thanks for your keen rebuke.
I know what you would say: Here stands our King,
Our sacred liege, namesake of Charlemagne,
And we, who take our dignities from him,
And only shine because we are his servants,
Much it becomes us now, in his great need,
To be no more his gossips, chamberlains
And poetasters —
but his soldiers. Pray,
Sieur La Tremouille, throw this in the fire:
This is that little rondel on the weather.

div.stage: With emotion, he offers his hand to La Tremouille, who refuses it icily

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Your fire will scarce prevent its raining still,
If Heaven so wills it, sir.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: At first feels the repulse keenly, then speaks in quiet disdain
sp.l: True, if Heaven wills it.

div.stage: Turning to the hearth, D'Alençon throws the parchment into the flames

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: D'Alençon — thanks!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Our scrimmage now is on.
Let see which wins.

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: The duke was warm.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: La! Let
Our little King still dream his name is France.
Sure, he will soon believe this milking-maid
Who comes to crown him.

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: Milking-maid?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Why, she
Who rode in town the eve of yesterday,
The soldier-shepherdess, — Jeanne la Pucelle,
The people call her.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: The dear people love
To label any peasant drab a "virgin,"
And every charlatan a "shepherdess."

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Tonnerre de dieu! What man hath seen the face
Of Jeanne the Maid and named her charlatan?
Her face — God's eyes! When I am cooked and damn'd,
And devils twirl me on a spit in hell,
I'll think upon that face and have redemption.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: Who has listened with eager interest
sp.l: Then you have seen her?

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Once, and ever since
My fingers have been itching at my sword
To crack an English skull and win her smile.

sp.speaker: DIANE
sp.l: O miracles! Monsieur the Growler speaks
In praise of women.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Ah, my love, but think
How man's gear doth become the maiden shape.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: And if she be not white as maidenhood,
I will — before these ladies and your Grace —
Pluck out mine eye-teeth.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Save them, sir; 'tis plain
She hath already plucked your wisdom out.
I do not love this Jeanne.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: I do, Seigneur.

sp.speaker: ATHENIE
sp.l: He'd better have drunk poison than said that.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Marshal La Hire, your hand! Fame hath described you —
Your pardon! — as a rake-hell, hydrophobious
Gascon, who bites at all men —
even favourites.
I pray, sir, as the fire regales the hearth-mouse,
Grant me your friendship.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Sir, you have it — hot.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: This Jeanne the Maid, you think she is — inspired?

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: No, sir! — I know it.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: This will interest
His Majesty: pray, will you tell him more?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: Watching D'Alençon escort La Hire to Charles
sp.l: By God, the man usurps me.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: But I thought
You laid an ambush for this charlatan
To keep her from the King.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: The plan failed. Now
She is quartered here within the castle tower.
The doctors of Poitiers are with her there,
Cross-questioning her faith and sanity.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Will, then, the King receive her?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: He must not.
No; from this castle's tower she must depart
Back to Lorraine.
These babblers must be hushed,
And Jeanne's reception foiled. Such sparks make flames.
Already she hath kindled the people; soon
She might inflame the King himself to action;
Then — follow me! If France should whip the English,
Charles would be solvent.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: And you really fear
Lest one weak girl shall overturn the world?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: One should fear nothing; what one knows is this:
'Well for oneself is well enough for the world.'
In short, at present all is well for me .

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: To Vendôme, who has entered and spoken with him
sp.l: Bring here the men; they shall be very welcome.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Our livers are too fat, your Majesty.
We Frenchmen are a herd of potted geese,
A paté de fois gras to cram the bellies
Of British mongrels.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Still, sir, —

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Ventre du diable!
Flanders, Artois, Champagne, and Picardy,
Normandy — gobbled, all of 'em! And now
Talbot, the English mastiff, with his whelps,
Squats on his haunch and howls at Orleans' gate,
And Scales and Suffolk bark around the walls.
God's bones! and what do we? Seize up our cudgels
And drive the curs back to their island-kennel?
Nay, sire, we scare 'em off with nursery-songs.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: You speak your mind a little harshly, Marshal?

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.stage: To a servant who has come to him from La Tremouille
sp.l: I keep but one about me, sire, and that
Is likely to go off in people's noses
Like this new brand of snuff called gunpowder.
His grace would wish to speak with me? — Delighted!

div.stage: He follows the servant to La Tremouille, who speaks aside to him

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: Utterly dejected by La Hire's words
sp.l: What can I do, D'Alençon? I am pawned
And patched and mortgaged to my finger-nails.
The very turnspits in the kitchen whistle
For wages at me, and I bid them whistle.
What can I do but play at King?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: A change
Of policy would bring you instant funds.
Your people would recover your lost cities,
If you would captain them.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: My people! Ah!
'Tis God alone could make this people mine,
By consecrated rite and taintless seed
From sire to royal son. I had a mother,
Who left me for her royal legacy
A monstrous doubt in a tiny syllable:
Legitimate or il legitimate? —
Cure me that ill, and I will conquer Europe.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Boethius saith, there is one antidote
To being born; that is — philosophy.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Excuse me, sir! This silence is too golden
For me to keep it by me. I have heard,
When I was hatched, the mid-wife split my tongue
And had me suckled by a certain jackdaw,
That was the village wet-nurse. — Who can vouch
For all one hears?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Silence must come to all:
To some a little sooner. — I have said.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: As soon as God shall have your Grace's permit,

I shall be ready!
( Lower )
Yet I warn your Grace,
Bury me not too shallow under sod,
Lest, where the stink is, other jackdaws scratch
And cause your Grace's nose embarrassment.

div.stage: Reënter Vendôme, followed by DE METZ and DE POULANGY, whom he escorts to D'Alençon and Charles

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Mine: Jean de Metz, servant of France.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: And yours?

sp.speaker: DE POULANGY
sp.l: Bertrand de Poulangy.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Your master?

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Robert de Baudricourt of Vaucouleurs.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: He sent you to conduct this shepherdess
Here to our castle?

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: And beseech you, King,
To give her audience.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: You travelled shrewdly
To escape the English and Burgundians.
They hold the river-bridges and the fords.

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: We escaped by miracle: at black of night,
We swam our horses through the swollen streams;
At dawn, we couched in hiding; at our side
She slept all day in armour; and we prayed.
It was the Maid who brought us safely here.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Nay, but you say you were in hiding.

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Yet
It was the Maid; she said it should be so.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Can she, then, prophesy?

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: She is from God.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: You told us — from Lorraine!

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Even so from God.
Out of Lorraine, beside the Ladies' Tree,
Shall come a maid — saviour of France.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: A legend old as Merlin.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: And as heathen.
You are dismissed.

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Beseech your Majesty
To grant her audience!

sp.speaker: DE POULANGY
sp.l: She is from God.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: That shall the judgment of the Church decide.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: The door is open.

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Gracious King!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: But George —

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Don't fear; the beggars shall not plague thee, boy.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Nay, by St. Denis! but they plague me not.
A March-mad peasant-wench will pass the time.
I'll see the lass.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: Dismissing De Metz and De Poulangy with a gesture
sp.l: Good-nature kills thee, Charles.
His Majesty regrets —

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: His Majesty
Regrets he might not sooner speak with her.
Vendôme, go with these men, and tell the Maid
The King will see her now.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Sir, is this wise?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Whether 'tis wise, your Grace, depends perhaps
Whether one holds a first or second mortgage.
Foreclosure of a second might be folly.

div.stage: A slight pause

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: What's this — a parable?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Why, what you please;
Call it a hook and line. I knew a man
Who turned fish-monger of an Easter eve.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: With a piqued smile and shrug .]
As De Metz and De Poulangy go out, he turns aside to De Chartres
sp.l: Nonsense prevails!
The devil fetch this duke!
I would I knew what he hath loaned to Charles.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: "Out of Lorraine, beside the Ladies' Tree,
Shall come a maid — saviour of France." — D'Alençon!
What if this wench, green from her vines and cheeses,
Her sheep-shears and her spindle, should dispel
My sovereign doubt. — Nay, listen! If she be
From God indeed, and I be truly King,
She should detect my royal sanctity
Under what guise soever; ought she not?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: There are some powers of nature little known.
But what may be your plan?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: I say, unless
She be a charlatan, or I base-born,
She'll recognize me by her holy vision
As King amongst a thousand.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: That must follow,
Of course.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I think it follows not; but, sire,
What means of testing —

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: This! She comes but newly
From far Lorraine, hath never seen my face,
Nor heard my voice, nor set foot in this hall.
Good! You and I, D'Alençon, shall change cloaks,
You shall be King — she hath not seen thee?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Good! I will be D'Alençon and stand here
One of the court, subordinate, whilst you
Sit yonder on the throne-chair — Charles of France.
Then let her enter.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Bravo, Charles! A plot
Of genius!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Nay, a pleasant ruse.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: But if
She fail to uncloak the counterfeit? Such slips
Are common to the best of us.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: At least
We shall have killed an hour in a new way,
And one less hoax to trouble us.

sp.speaker: VENDÔME
sp.l: The Maid!
The reverend masters are conducting her
Here to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Be quick, D'Alençon!

div.stage: As Charles, stripping off his outer garment, reaches it to D'Alençon, La Tremouille beckons Vendôme to himself

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: You wish it, sire?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: At once.

div.stage: They exchange cloaks, but the placard of King Dagobert is discarded to a servant

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: To Vendôme, indicating to him the fact of the exchange
With an exultant smile, to De Chartres
sp.l: You understand.
This whim of Charles's relieves us of much pains.
Look where he prays to the glass emperor.

div.stage: La Tremouille points at Charles, who — wearing D' Alençon's cloak of dun — stands beneath the window of stained glass, and supplicates if, apart

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Thou, Charlemagne, dead sire and mighty saint!
If in my veins thy hallowed blood still runs,
Let through this mean disguise thy royal spirit shine,
And make, in me, thy race and honour manifest.

div.stage: D'Alençon, wearing Charles's royal cloak, sits on the throne. All those present range themselves as his subjects, some standing near, others closing about Charles, where he stands ( right centre ). Reënter then, at back, Vendôme, followed by DOCTORS of the Church; these by De Metz and De Poulangy, who stand by the door; last enters Jeanne, dressed as a man. The Doctors, exchanging with Vendôme a hardly detectable look of understanding, approach D'Alençon, make their obeisances, and stand away. Vendôme, motioning then to Jeanne, moves forward to conduct her to D'Alençon as king, but pauses as she does not follow. Standing in the doorway, Jeanne, lifting her face intensely toward the stained-glass window, seems to listen. At the same moment, while the eyes of all are centred upon Jeanne, there emerges from the great fireplace, where logs are burning, and stands upon the hearth with flaming wings, St. Michael, who gazes also at Jeanne. The only sound or other motion in the hall is caused by the Court-fool, who, springing up from the throne-footstool to whisper of the Maid in D'Alençon's ear, sets thereby the bells on his cap to tinkling silverly. Simultaneously, the voice of St. Catherine speaks, as from mid-air

sp.speaker: THE VOICE
sp.l: Daughter of God, choose boldly.

div.stage: Glancing slowly through the hall, the eyes of Jeanne meet those of St. Michael, who points with his hand at Charles, then turns and disappears within the smoke and glow of the fireplace. Moving then with decision, Jeanne follows Vendôme, but oblivious of D'Alençon, passes on straight to Charles, before whom she kneels down

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Gentle Dauphin,
My name is Jeanne the Maid, and I am come
To bring you tidings from the King of Heaven
That He by means of me shall consecrate
And crown you King at Rheims.

div.stage: The hall remains silent and awed. Charles is visibly moved

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: I am not the King.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Truly you are the Dauphin — Charles of France,
Who shall be King when God anointeth you
In His cathedral.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: By my fay, young maid,
Thou dost not flatter us with homage. Rise
And stand before us. We are Charles of France.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I rise, Seigneur, but not unto the King.
You are not Charles of France.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.stage: With emotion, aside to La Tremouille
sp.l: This troubles me.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: We have been tricked somewhere.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: 'Tis plain, good Jeanne,
That thou art wandered in some winter's tale,
Wherein lèse-majesté to fairy-princes
Doth little matter. You are smiling? What
Do we remind you on?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: In truth, Seigneur,
At home in Domremy where I was born
There lives an old good-wife, who used to tell
How Master Donkey wore King Lion's mane.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Tonnerre!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Nay, honourable lords, and you
Fair gentlewomen, truly am I come
Into your midst — a sheep-maid dull and rude.
Pass on! Of that no more. But which of you
Hath cunning to deceive the sight of God?
Or which would speak a lie unto his Lord?
My Lord hath sent me here, His messenger,
But He hath girt me with a thousand more
Whose eyes are many as the nesting birds
And voices as cicadas in the summer.
Lo! in this hall they hover o'er you now,
But your dissembling eyes send up a mist
To obscure their shining wings. O gentles, mock
No more, but show God your true faces!

div.stage: A pause, filled with the various pantomime of uneasiness, admiration, and wonder. All look for decision to D'Alençon

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Maid,
I lied to you. I am the Duke d'Alençon.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Dearer to France as duke than King, Seigneur.

div.stage: She extends to him her hand — strong, peasantly, with a frank smile. He takes it, amazed, and unconsciously continues to hold it

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: She knew me, George! Unswervingly, at once,
In spite of all our cunning. —

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Hm!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: She knew me;
George! but you saw.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: These charlatans are shrewd

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: What? — What!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: I cannot say.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: But you beheld,
Behold!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: It may be. — I have heard — who knows
What hidden conspirator — Satan perhaps.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Satan!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Why not?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: D'Alençon, question her!
What deem you of this proof? What is this maid?

div.stage: D'Alençon, having started at being addressed, has released Jeanne's hand

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I know not, sire. — 'Tis that which fascinates me.

div.stage: Looking again at Jeanne with his former friendly puzzled look, he hesitates, then speaks, embarrassed. Throughout the following brief scene — stirred by mingled mystification and admiration of the peasant girl — he, in his questioning, halts occasionally; in which gaps La Tremouille steps shrewdly in

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Jeanne d'Arc, you have well stood — or seemed to stand —
Our playful ruse — his Majesty's and mine —
To test your boasted powers.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I have no powers
To boast, Seigneur.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: You have been catechised
Already by these reverend Doctors here?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Since dawn they have not ceased to question me.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: What is your verdict thus far, Master Seguin?

sp.speaker: SEGUIN
sp.l: Your Grace, we find no fault in her.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Come, come;
Now you are needed.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: I believe in her.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Our privy council fails us now?

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Her face!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Pardieu!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: What is this boon which you have come
To beg his Majesty?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I beg, Seigneur,
A troop of the good fighting-men of France,
That I may lead them, by the help of God,
To drive from France the wicked Englishmen
That 'siege his town of Orleans.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Sacré bleu!
Boil 'em in peppermint.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: To Jeanne, intervening, as D'Alençon gazes in admiration
sp.l: Most excellent!
That thou, a shepherd lass, shouldst leave thy wool
To instruct our captains in the craft of war.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My Lord hath willed it so.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Who is thy lord?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The King of Heaven that is the King of France
Till He shall crown the Dauphin.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Sir, your pardon:
I am now catechiser. — Slowly, Jeanne:
If God hath willed to bring deliverance
To France, then soldiers are superfluous.
Why do you ask for soldiers?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: En nom Dé!
The soldiers are to fight, and God to give
The victory.

div.stage: Murmurs of approbation

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: You do not then believe
In God His power?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Better than you, Seigneur.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: At first amused, then strangely moved by this character-reading, drops again the thread of his questioning in self-revery
sp.l: Better than I!

div.stage: He continues to watch and listen to Jeanne, absorbed in her as in some problem unsolved

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: You have observed, my friends,
The circling orbit of these arguments,
That veer like swallows round a chimney hole.
Clearly we must await some valid sign
Before we trust this maid.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My noble masters!
I come not to Chinon to show you signs,
But give me those good fighters, and for sign
I will deliver Orleans.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Have you, then,
No other sign to show?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I have, indeed,
A sign — but not for you. It may be seen
By one alone, my Dauphin.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Me! By me?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: O gentle Dauphin, by the love you bear
To France, and by the love of France for you,
Hear me — but not with these.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Leave us alone.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Remember, Charles, what black confederate
Instructs this man-maid.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Let the court withdraw.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: I stay, my dear!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Very quietly, standing with her eyes focussed far
sp.l: The Seigneur will withdraw.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: Drawing away after the others toward the stairway, overtakes De Chartres, aside .]
sp.l: She is possessed.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: By angels.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Friend La Hire,
How much of miracle, think you, do we
Ignore in simple nature?

div.stage: Charles is now left alone with Jeanne, beyond the others' hearing

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Shepherdess,
How knewest thou it was I, among the many?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My Voices said, "Choose boldly," and I knew.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: What voices, Jeanne?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: You must believe in me
To hear them.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Tell me; is it known of them
Or thee — this doubt which is my stain and cancer?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: That doubt is as the darkness of the blind
Which is not.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Is not? Oh, give me the sign!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: You must believe before you may behold.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Look in my eyes, Jeanne; I begin to see.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My Dauphin must believe; he shall believe.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: The crown!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Believe!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: He lifts it.

div.stage: The clock begins to chime. In the same instant, the sunlit form of the Emperor in the stained glass is seen to turn toward the King — where he gazes at him past the face of Jeanne — and to hold out aloft the glowing crown of fleur-de-lis. From the colonnade, the persons of the court look on, whisper together, pointing at the King, where apparently he is kneeling, struck with adoration, at the feet of Jeanne. D'Alençon, standing forward from the rest of the court, is intent upon Jeanne, as, with the inward light of a vision mirrored, her face looks down on the King with a mighty intensity

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR IN THE STAINED GLASS
sp.stage: Speaks with the voice of St. Michael
sp.l: Charles the Seventh!
Inheritor of France, legitimate
By birth —

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Legitimate!

sp.speaker: THE EMPEROR
sp.l: Behold the crown —
The crown of Charlemagne — which thou shalt wear
At Rheims. This is the Maid, whom God hath sent
To bring thy land and thee deliverance.

div.stage: As the chiming ceases, so the vision. Charles — his hands clasped — rises wildly to his feet .]

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Charlemagne! Charlemagne! Thy blood is vindicated.
My lords, this is the Maid of God!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Staggering slightly as with faintness, moves toward D'Alençon, who comes to her side
sp.l: I am tired;
Thy shoulder, friend!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: Kneels again, his arms upraised to the stained glass
sp.l: Charlemagne!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: As Jeanne rests her forehead on his shoulder, speaks to himself dreamily
sp.l: Why, 'tis a child!

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: SCENE: A Meadow before the Walls of Orleans. May 7, 1429.

In the near background ( occupying a large part of the scene ) a green knoll overlooks the not distant river Loire flowing toward the right, and a part of the city wall, which sweeps beyond view, left. On this knoll are discovered Franciscan friars grouped about an altar, beside which floats a white painted banner, sprinkled with fleur-de-lis. [Note: 1Kb On one side of this banner (which, authentically, was Jeanne's personal standard) is depicted — on the ground of fleur-de-lis — Christ in Glory, holding the world and giving His benediction to a lily, held by one of two angels, who are kneeling at each side; on the other side the figure of the Virgin and a shield with the arms of France, supported by two angels. The friars also have in their charge two smaller banners, viz.: one a pennon, on which is represented the Annunciation; the other, a banneret, adorned with the Crucifixion. One of these friars , PIGACHON, is dressed half in armour, his cassock — worn over a steel corslet — being tucked up, thus revealing his legs encased in steel. On the left of the scene are women, old men, and priests of Orleans. The foreground and the rest of the adjacent meadow are thronged with French officers and soldiery. In the midst of the latter ( centre ), Jeanne d'Arc — in full armour — is dictating a letter, which PASQUEREL, her confessor, transcribes on a parchment .

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.p: "King of England; and you, Duke of Bedford, who call yourself Regent of the Kingdom of France; you, William De la Pole, Earl of Suffolk; John, Lord Talbot; and you, Thomas Lord Scales, Lieutenants of the same duke; make satisfaction to the King of Heaven; give up to the Maid, who is sent hither by God, the keys of all the good towns in France, which ye have taken. And as for you, archers, companions-in-arms, gentlemen, and others who are before this town of Orleans, get you home to your own country by God His command; and if this be not done, then once more will we come upon you with so great an ha, ha! as shall be remembered these thousand years. Answer now if ye will make peace in this city of Orleans, which if ye do not, ye may be reminded on, to your much hurt.
sp.l: Jhesus Maria — Jehanne la Pucelle."
Good Pasquerel, I know not A nor B;
Where shall I make my cross?

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Here, Angelique.

div.stage: Jeanne makes her cross on the parchment, which she then rolls tight and ties to an arrow

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: De Metz, ride to the bridge and shoot this arrow
Across the Loire into the English lines. —
Wait, aim it toward the tower of the Tournelles
Into the conning-shaft where Suffolk stands.

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: And if they make no answer?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: We have fought
Since daybreak. We can fight again till dark;
And after that to-morrow, and to-morrow.

div.stage: Exit De Metz, with the arrow, amid shouts of the people and soldiers

sp.speaker: DUNOIS
sp.l: Your words are brave, Pucelle, and they are holy;
But holy words are weak against stone walls.
The English fortress is too strong for us.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Now by the hang'd thieves of Gethsemane!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Gascon!

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
