sp.l: Forgive, my captain: by my stick!
I swear to God I swore but by my stick.
You said a man might curse upon his stick.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Pulling his ear with her hand .]
sp.l: You do well to bethink you, Marshal; mind,
Who spits 'gainst Heaven, it falleth on his head.
But thou art my brave Growler for all that!

div.stage: Jeanne passes to speak earnestly to other officers

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Now by my stick, Dunois, without offence,
Thou liest in thy windpipe and thy gorge
To say the English walls are made of stone;
And if the Maid of God shall say the word,
By supper-time we'll roll 'em out as flat
As apple-jacks, with English blood for syrup.

sp.speaker: DUNOIS
sp.l: Truly the Maid of God hath wrought strange things
Yet there be bounds —

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Eight days! Eight days! Dunois,
Since she set foot in Orleans, and look now!
The enemy that hemmed you in a web
Of twenty fortresses now holds but one.

sp.speaker: DUNOIS
sp.l: But that one — the Tournelles!

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: And think ye, then,
That she who turns French poodles into lions,
And changes British mastiffs into hares,
Will find it difficult to change yon tower
Into a sugar-loaf? I tell thee, man,
She is from God, and doth whatso she will.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: To D'Alençon, who in his armour stands reading
sp.l: A book, my knight? And your good sword yet hot?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The war-horse, Jeanne, still craves his manger-oats. —
My book is a little island in the battle,
And I am moored alongside in this lull
To barter with strange natives — deeds, for dreams
Of deeds.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Is it the holy gospel?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Whereof, then, do you read?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Of you, Madonna!
When you were virgin-queen of Attica,
And all your maiden Amazons in arms
Hailed you "Hippolyta."

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Putting from him the book, hands him his sword with a friendly smile
sp.l: This is your sword,
My bonny duke; and this dear ground is France.
I know naught of your queens and "anticas."

sp.speaker: A PRIEST
sp.l: Jeanne! Jeanne the Maid!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: THE PRIEST
sp.l: Speak to us —
What of the battle?

sp.speaker: SEVERAL VOICES
sp.l: Tell us! Speak to us!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Good folk, you hearts of Orleans, holy fathers!
What would you that I tell you?

sp.speaker: SEVERAL VOICES
sp.l: Prophesy!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: [LOUIS DE CONTES blows the horn once
sp.l: Ah, friends, if you would hear of bloody stars,
Of sun-dogs, and of mare's tails in the dawn,
Go to your gossips and your weather-wives;
'Tis ours to fight and God's to prophesy.
Yet what our Lord hath spoken by His Saints
To me, I speak to you again: be glad,
For not in vain, good men, have you stood strong
And shared your loaves of famine, crumb by crumb,
To man your walls against our wicked foe;
And not in vain, mothers of Orleans, you
Have rocked your cradles by the cannon's side
To bring your sons and husbands ease of sleep;
For you have kept this city for your Lord,
Which is the King of Heaven, and He hath come
To recompense you now. Therefore, return
Within your gates again, and when you hear,
Thrice blown, upon this horn, God's warning blast,
Then ring your bells for France and victory.
Louis, the horn!
So shall you know His sign.

div.stage: The people depart with gestures of benediction and hope

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: Standing with La Hire, near Jeanne
sp.l: A child! and her clear eyes, upturned to Heaven,
Shall influence the stars of all the ages.
La Hire! We are living now , can watch, can serve her!

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Aye, folk that live in other times are damned.

div.stage: An altar bell sounds

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: The Vespers, Angelique.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: All kneel, save some few, who depart, abashed. Among these is D'Alençon, whom Jeanne stays wistfully
sp.l: Soldiers, the Mass!
And let all you that have confessed yourselves
This day, kneel down, and let the rest depart
Until confession.
You , my duke?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I am
A tardy Christian, Jeanne.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I pray you kneel
Beside, me. My good Pasquerel will hear you.

div.stage: D'Alençon kneels beside Jeanne and Pasquerel; Pigachon among the friars is about to conduct the service at the altar, when De Metz's voice is heard calling ( off right ), and he enters, followed immediately by an English Herald, who, bearing himself defiant, holds in his hand a parchment

sp.speaker: DE METZ
sp.l: Jeanne! — Maid of God!

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH HERALD
sp.l: Where is the whore of France?

div.stage: The kneeling soldiers start up in turbulence

sp.speaker: SOLDIERS
sp.l: La Mort! La Mort!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Peace! Let the herald speak;

His privilege is sacred.
( To D'Alençon )
Stop them.

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.l: Where
Is she who calls herself the Maid of God?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I am the Maid.

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.stage: Speaking, but at times referring with his eyes to the parchment
sp.l: Thus saith my Lord, the King
Of England, by his servant Suffolk, Captain
Before the walls of Orleans: Whore of France —

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Death! —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Stay! He speaks not for himself, but Suffolk;
His cloth is holy.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Holy!

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.l: Courtesan
Of him who shames the blood of Charlemagne,
Consort of Satan, which hast ta'en the limbs
And outward seeming of a peasant wench
To execute thy damnèd sorceries
On England's sons, to please thy paramour —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: To the soldiers, who grow more clamorous
sp.l: Yet patience, garçons!

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.l: Thou unvirgin thing,
Which art vaingloried in the garb of man;
Thou impudent, thou subtle, thou unclean —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: No, no! Thou hast forgot what thou shouldst say!

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.l: Thus fling we back thy poison'd script unread,
And therewith this defiance: Work thy worst,
And with the hand of strange paralysis
Strike numb with fear our noble English host;
Yet shall we still resist thee with our souls,
And in the day when Christ shall let thee fall
Within our power, then shalt thou make amends
In fire for all thy witchcraft, and in fire
Shall thy unhallow'd spirit return to hell.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Hold, gentlemen! Wait yet if he have done
This "holy privilege" of infamy.

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.l: Sir, I am done.

div.stage: D'Alençon, taking the little pennon of the Annunciation from a friar, hands it to the Herald

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Take, then, this back with you
In token who it is whom you profane.
Lock it within your fortress' strongest tower,
And tell your masters that a simple maid
Of France shall fetch it home, this night, to Orleans.

div.stage: Exit Herald with pennon. The soldiers mutter applause and execrations

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Hiding her face, turns to D'Alençon
sp.l: What have I done that they should name me so?

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Par mon baton! We'll answer them in blood.

sp.speaker: DUNOIS
sp.l: Your places, officers!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Starts to Pigachon and the soldiers
sp.l: The psalm! Your psalm!

div.stage: Pigachon and the friars raise the chant of the hymn of Charlemagne. This is immediately taken up by all the soldiers, who, under its influence, pass out in solemn enthusiasm, led by D'Alençon and Jeanne, the latter carrying in her hand the banneret with the Crucifixion

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Veni creator Spiritus ,
Mentes tuorum visita ,
Imple superna gratia
Quæ tu creasti pectora .

div.stage: There now remain behind only Pasquerel and the Franciscan friars, grouped around Jeanne's standard of the fleur-de-lis. These continue the chant in a low tone, as the voices of the soldiers grow fainter in the distance

sp.speaker: FRIARS
sp.l: Qui paraclitus diceris
Donum Dei altissimi
Fons vivus, ignis, caritas
Et spiritalis unctio .
Hostem repellas longius
Pacemque dones protinus ,
Ductore sic te prævio
Vitemus omne noxium .

div.stage: During the last verses Pasquerel, having examined the banner critically, fetches a copper box, opens it, lays out some sewing and painting materials, lowers the banner, and bends over it solicitously. With the last words of the chant, a serene quiet falls upon the knoll, save when, from time to time, contrasting sounds of the distant battle interrupt, or fill the pauses of the conversation between Pasquerel and Pigachon .]

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Reach me my palette yonder, Pigachon.
Our Lord hath something scathed his brow and lip
I' the last mêlée, and one of his white lilies
Is smirched with river-slime. Take you my needle
And hem this ravell'd edge, whilst I retouch
The Saviour's robe and face.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: The crimson silk
Or white?

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: The white is better for the hem.
Now for our Lord, what say you? — to the lip
A touch of Garence rose? I much prefer
Myself, for blush and richness of the blood,
A Garence rose dorée to cinnabar;
Yet thereof Master Fra Angelico
Of Florence might be critical.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: May be.

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Well, masters think not two alike.
Voilà!
Saw you the mauve and pink geraniums
In Brother Michel's hot-bed?

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: Wonderful!

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: He waters them at prime and curfew.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: Ha!

div.stage: Silence again; the two friars work on .]

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: I have it, Pigachon! It comes to me!
To touch this lily's petal-tips with rose
In token that it bleeds.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: Why does it bleed?

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: But thou art mule-brain'd, Pigachon. Know, then,
It bleeds for sorrow of its little sisters,
The fleur-de-lis of France, because they lie
Bleeding and trampled by the fiends of England.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Yet perchance the Maid might disapprove.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: May be.

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Well, well; I will not make it bleed.

div.stage: Enter, amid louder cries from the battle, Louis de Contes with two men, fettered

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: THE FIRST MAN
sp.l: John Gris, Knight to the King of England.

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: Yours?

sp.speaker: THE OTHER
sp.l: Adam Goodspeed, yeoman.

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: John Gris, Knight,
And Adam Goodspeed, yeoman, you are bound
As prisoners to Louis, called De Contes,
Page to God's maiden Jeanne, called La Pucelle.

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: Sith God hath dropped us in the Devil's clutch,
His will be done.

sp.speaker: GOODSPEED
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.stage: Springing up from his paints, stares off scene ( right ), appalled
sp.l: O dolorosa!

div.stage: Enter D'Alençon, supporting Jeanne, and followed by La Hire and a group of soldiers

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Go back, La Hire: let not this thing be known.

div.stage: Exeunt La Hire and soldiers .]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Where is my standard? Rest me here.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The gates
Are but a little farther.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: In God's name
I will not leave the field. — My standard!

div.stage: She sinks down beside it

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Run!
Fetch from the town a litter.
Have you oil?
Prepare a heated compress for the wound;
She is stricken and may die.

div.stage: Louis, after fastening his prisoners to a log ( left ), departs with a friar. Pasquerel, after lighting a charcoal brazier, begins with D'Alençon's help to tear and fold a bandage

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Good Pigachon!

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: You called me, Angelique?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Go to my men
And tell them I am well.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: A lie?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: A little,
A white lie: God will make of it a star
To shine on Orleans when she is delivered.

sp.speaker: PIGACHON
sp.l: I go.

div.stage: Exit right

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Would I might tell a lie for her!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: No, dear my bonny duke, you shall not touch;
I'll pluck it out myself.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Thou must not, Jeanne;
The barb hath sunken deep; thou art but a girl.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I am a soldier. — Think you it will bleed?
Ah, Heaven, if it should bleed!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: As Jeanne, turning away, clutches at her side
sp.l: What dost thou?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: See,
There is the arrow. I will keep my eyes
A little shut —

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: She's dying, Pasquerel;
She's torn the arrow forth with her own hand.
Help me to bear her to the city gate.

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: She said beside her standard.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: But, thou sot
Of superstition, she is dying. Are
Her wishes dearer to thee than her life?

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: She is from God.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: O idiotic phrase!
We soldiers babble it like paraquets,
And let a child — this brave and dreamy girl —
Die in the sacrifice for us — for us!
Jeanne, thou must live — Jeanne! Though all France shall find
Perdition, thou must live!

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Unholy words!
She lives for France.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: Eagerly, as Jeanne lifts her head
sp.l: She lives; it is enough!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Good neighbour, say to him I had to come.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My father. You will tell him?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Truly.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: You know, we have two fathers; one's in heaven.
We must obey the greater. — Was he angry?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I think he was not angry.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: That is strange;
His scowl is terrible, and yet he loves us:
My brother Pierre and me the most, I think.
What did he do the day I went away?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Dost thou not know me, Jeanne?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I know thee well.
Thou art the face that comes to my closed eyes,
And in the darkness there I speak to it. —
I knew my mother she would understand,
For often I told her how my Voices said
That I must crown the King, and she would smile,
But always Papa Jacques he scowled.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Now gently;
Rest back upon my arm; this is thy friend
D'ALENÇON. — So!

div.stage: Pasquerel and D'Alençon put upon her the compress

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My mother hurts me here.
They said it was an arrow in my side,
But I knew well it was the homesickness,
And so I plucked it out, and gave 't to him
My Lord, because it had no business there.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: To me you gave it, Jeanne, not to your Lord.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: And are you not His knight whom God hath sent
To be my shield in battle? — Verily
I leaned upon your shoulder at Chinon
When I was weary and the world grew dim. —
Thou art D'Alençon and my bonny duke.

div.stage: Reënter ( left ) Louis and the friar with a litter

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I am your servant, and must bear you now
Back to the town.

sp.speaker: DISTANT CRIES
sp.l: La Pucelle! Au secours!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: You hear! I cannot go. They call for me.
Fetch me my horse.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Madonna, you may die.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I may not die before I have performed
My Lord's commandment; they have told me so.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Who told?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My Voices.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Jeanne, for love of France
And truth and thy dear soul, lose not thy life
For vanities and whisperings of the air.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Know you whereof you speak?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I speak of nothing,
For they are naught.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My holy counsel — naught!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Do not believe them, Jeanne. They are delusions.
Forgive me! I must speak the truth to save
Thy life.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: If this were true, O better death!
But listen!

div.stage: The Franciscans about the altar are beginning to move it from the knoll to the level ground ( on the left ).]

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Come now with me. Be a good girl.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Listen, my duke.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: 'Tis but a friar, bearing
The altar bell.

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.stage: Speaks with the bell, which sounds momentarily as the friar moves it
sp.l: Daughter of God, be strong.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Gazing before her into Pasquerel's lighted brazier
sp.l: It is her voice; it is St. Catherine.
See in the little flames how small she shines
And flutters like a moth mid peonies.
But holy saints fear not to singe their wings
In fire. You see, she is not frightened.

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: Pater ,
Sanctum sit nomen tuum .

sp.speaker: GOODSPEED
sp.l: Turn thine eyes
Away! The witch beginneth her hell charms.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Thou dear St. Catherine, I will be strong!

sp.speaker: PASQUEREL
sp.l: And will you now believe?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: This is a strength
Unnatural, a fever from the wound.
Jeanne —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Look, D'Alençon, look, they leave the bridge!
Our men have turned. Alas! They are beaten back.

div.stage: Enter La Hire, beside himself .]

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Lord God, I pray Thee, do Thou for La Hire
What he would do for Thee, if he were God,
And Thou, God, wert La Hire!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: What news, and quickly!

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: News for the rats and skunks of Europe! News
For dancing apes and Master Rigadoons!
Dunois himself hath bade our men retreat,
And me, La Hire, to tell it!

sp.speaker: CRIES
sp.l: To the gates!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Dunois, Dunois, thou hast offended me.

sp.speaker: CRIES
sp.l: The gates!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Our men — they come. — Jeanne, you will fall.
Stay! — I will rally them.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Climbing faintly the knoll, as D'Alençon comes to her support
sp.l: Still be my shield.

div.stage: Enter Dunois and the French soldiery, in rout

sp.speaker: CRIES
sp.l: The gates of Orleans!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: From the knoll, speaking from D'Alençon's arms, which uphold her, stays the rout .]
sp.l: Halt!

sp.speaker: CRIES
sp.l: The Maid! The Maid!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Who hath commanded you this thing?

sp.speaker: DUNOIS
sp.l: Jeanne d'Arc,
The English fortress is impregnable.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Dunois, heaven's fortress is impregnable
By souls of gentlemen who turn their backs.

sp.speaker: DUNOIS
sp.l: You fell; we saw how you were wounded, Maid.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: And ye beheld not One who did not fall:
Shame, captains of France! Have ye not heard
"Better a dog's head than a lion's tail"?
Back to the bridge and show your teeth again!
Back to the bridge and show to God your eyes!

sp.speaker: SOLDIERS
sp.l: Back to the bridge!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My banner, dear my duke!
Come, we will go together, hand in hand. —
Children of France, behold your fleur-de-lis!
Thou, Louis, stay, and when thou shalt have seen
This banner touch the English walls — thy horn!
Blow it at Orleans' gate: the siege is raised!
Follow your lilies now, brave boys of France!
Your lilies! Christ the Lord doth captain you.
Ten thousand of his host surround us. See!
The sun goes down through archings of their wings,
The river burns and eddies with their swords.
Work, work, and God will work! Follow the lilies
And shoot your arrows straight. — Jhesus-Maria!

sp.speaker: SOLDIERS
sp.l: Jhesus-Maria! — St. Denis! La France!

div.stage: Exeunt all but Louis de Contes, in the foreground ( right ), and the two English prisoners tied, on the left, below the knoll. The Franciscans have been led away by Pasquerel toward the town, carrying with them the altar

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: I looked long in her face. Gentle it seemed
And beautiful.

sp.speaker: GOODSPEED
sp.l: So did the serpent's seem
In Adam's garden. Oh, the fiend is wise,
And in a witch's face most damnèd fair.

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: Indeed, the spell of her is strange upon me.
Where is her banner now?

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: I cannot see;
The low sun hurts my eyes; which way I look
It stares me like a monstrous waning moon
Winked on the blood-red clouds of rolling dust.

sp.speaker: GOODSPEED
sp.l: More like it be the many-headed face
Of Satan mocking us.

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: The lilies, there!
The Maid! The Maid!

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: What! do we drive her back?

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: She drives you from the bridge. Her armour! — Now —
Oh, she is blown about and fluttered o'er
By clouds of little golden butterflies,
And where she thrusts her lilied banner through,
She glitters double — in the air and river.

sp.speaker: GOODSPEED
sp.l: Her fiends are blown up from the underworld
To succour her.

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: This spell upon me!

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: Ah!
They hurl you from the drawbridge. Christ! You drown.
Yonder her banner and the fleur-de-lis!
The Maid hath touched the walls. Vive la France!

div.stage: Rushing up the knoll, Louis turns toward Orleans and winds his horn three times. In an instant, from the left, a clamour of horns and shouts and bells reply. Away, on the right, the iron din of the battle is still heard. Behind the knoll's outline burns the bright red of sunset; against that, raising his horn, stands out the tense, lithe silhouette of the little page .]

div.head: SCENE I:
div.stage: Before the walls of Troyes. July 5, 1429. Night.

On the left ( up scene ), partly surrounded by cypress trees, the entrance of a pavilion-like tent ( extending off scene, left ) is closed by a mediæval tapestry. At centre, beneath the trees, stand two benches of wood, one higher than the other. On the right, a stack of arms, and behind that vague outlines of a camp. Throughout the scene's action, from time to time, officers and guards of the French army pass by, or are visible in their battle-gear, as portions of the scene. After the rising of the moon, the walls and towers of the town are dimly visible in the background . Enter, right, La Tremouille and CAUCHON, the latter in the garb of a layman .

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: That is her tent; those reddish stars, that move,
Are sentries on the city ramparts. Troyes
Still shuts its gates against the Maid, the last
To stand between Charles and his crown at Rheims.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: He will be crowned?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: We hope yet to prevent.
You heard me speak of Brother Richard, here,
Staying in Troyes. He is a preaching friar,
A kind of mendicant Demosthenes
Who holds the keys of power between his teeth,
And locks or opes the city with his tongue.
To-night he is coming to interview the Maid
To ascertain whether she be from God.
On that the town's surrender will depend.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: So then — ?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: I think I have forestalled the Maid.
A certain Catherine de la Rochelle —
But never mind. Our point is this: that you
Stand ready, when I will, to yield Jeanne d'Arc
Into the English hands, to burn for witchcraft.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: To burn by course of law.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: By law, of course!

div.stage: Enter at back De Chartres, followed by FLAVY.]

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Your Grace?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Ah, 'tis our man.
You've brought him?

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Here is our honest bishop from Beauvais,
Pierre Cauchon.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Ex officio , my lords!

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: Your secret shall be safe with us. — This, sirs,
Is Marshal Flavy.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: From Compiègne?

sp.speaker: FLAVY
sp.l: I am
Commander at Compiègne.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: He knows the plan?

sp.speaker: FLAVY
sp.l: I am to ask the help immediate
Of Jeanne the Maid against the enemy
That threaten my city.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: I explained to him

How this good friend
( indicates Cauchon )
will see to it that the English
Shall know the proper moment to attack
And lure the Maid to fight outside the walls.

sp.speaker: FLAVY
sp.l: A few French troopers will pass out with her,
And then — I am to pull the drawbridge up.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: She shall be treated by us justly, sirs,
By process of the law for heretics.

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: She is coming: I will go.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: What! not afraid
To catch a second ague?

sp.speaker: DE CHARTRES
sp.l: In her presence
All policy deserts me, I grow blind;
Once was enough.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Wait; we will go along
With you and fetch the King and Brother Richard.

div.stage: Exeunt La Tremouille, De Chartres, Cauchon, and Flavy ( right ). Enter, at left ( down scene ), Jeanne. She is closely followed by a group of various persons, — women, artisans, gentle-folk, — some of whom, drawing near, touch her cloak, try to kiss her hands

sp.speaker: SEVERAL VOICES
sp.l: Holy! holy! Hear us, Maid of God!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Good souls, what would ye ask of Jeanne the Maid?

sp.speaker: A WOMAN
sp.l: My babe is dead. Her little body's cold.
Oh, resurrect her!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Was thy child baptized?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.l: Yes, Angelique.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Then do not cry for her,
For she is playing now at Mary's knee.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER WOMAN
sp.l: Mine's newly born. Be godmother to him,
That he may prosper.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Let his name be Charles .

sp.speaker: A COURTIER
sp.l: My fortune, Maid! When shall my luck change?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: If
Your luck be lame, rub it with elbow-grease.

sp.speaker: A KNIGHT
sp.l: Jeanne d'Arc, my master sendeth me —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Who is
Your master?

sp.speaker: THE KNIGHT
sp.l: 'Tis a nobleman of France,
And prays you tell him which of the two popes
Of Rome or Avignon he should obey.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Tell him with God there is no politics;
Let him serve God. — Why do you touch your rings
To mine, good people?

sp.speaker: AN ARTISAN
sp.l: To be sanctified.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: The people depart; Jeanne stands with hands clasped. Enter from the tent Louis de Contes; seeing her thus, he kneels before her, worshipful
Seeing Louis on his knees, she drops impetuously beside him
sp.l: Oh, do not touch my hands. But if ye seek
Blessing, go home and kiss the old tired hands
Of your good mothers that have toiled for you;
Come not to me; good night, friends, and adieu!
What shall I do? — Ah, Monseigneur in heaven,
Protect me from their prayers! Let not this folk
Commit idolatry because of me,
Nor touch this body as a saintly thing.
Guard me, you dear and gracious Voices! — Still
Why do I think on what my duke he said:
"Do not believe them, Jeanne! They are delusions."
Dear God, let me forget, for I am tired;
Let Thy work be fulfilled and take me home.
No, no! Not thou, my Louis!

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: Angelique,
Why do you weep?

div.stage: Enter D'Alençon through the cypresses behind them

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The night — how great it is!
And we — how little and how weak we are!
That star is shining down on Domremy
Between the pear-tree boughs. I had not dreamed
How that the world would be so great and wide.

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: They say it reacheth even beyond Rome,
Though I was never there.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: It matters not;
It lieth all within Our Lady's arms. —
Tell me, my Louis, hast thou never played
At knucklebone?

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: You will not play with me!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: And may I not?

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: But you —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Sometimes we play
With pebbles; here are some.

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: But you! From you
The English fled at Orleans, and to you
The angels speak and the bright saints come down!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Rising, drops the pebbles slowly from her hand
sp.l: It seemed but yesterday: in dear Lorraine
There was a lass with a red petticoat,
And she was called "Jeannette."

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Madonna!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Thou!
Ah, me! I saw it. Why did you stand there?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Where, then?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Behind you! Over my left shoulder
I saw it rising, pale.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The moon!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: 'Tis full.
What bad news have you brought me?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The King!
What of the King?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The King is well.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: But thou?
Thou art in pain, my duke.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: It is not pain.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Go in and sleep. When I have need of thee,
I'll call.

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: I will nap lightly, Angelique.

div.stage: Exit into tent

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Now, now, my good knight, speak out plain: what news?
I cannot bear the sadness in your eyes.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: There is a sadness which belies its name
And grows immeasurably dear to joy.
The King —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: He is coming here to-night
To speak with you.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: More counsels? In God's name,
Let us not hold so long and many parleys
But march short-cut to Rheims.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: This town of Troyes
Holds for the English still.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: It will surrender.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: We have no engines for the siege.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I have sent
For Brother Richard. He will open the gates
To-morrow; the day after, we shall march
Straight on to Rheims.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Charles will not march to Rheims.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: What shall prevent?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: A vision from the Lord.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: D'Alençon! hath the King beheld a vision?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I did not say the King.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Who, then?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: A woman.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: O bonny duke, why art thou strange with me?
Be not like all the rest, careful and slow.
Speak to me bold and plain.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Forgive me, Jeanne,
My soul, too, is infected with this air
And breathes of weakness, innuendo, doubt;
But now, like thee, I will be bold and brief.
The woman Catherine de La Rochelle
Hath duped the Dauphin to believe in her
That she hath seen a vision out of heaven,
Declaring thee and all thy Voices false.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Ha, by St John! And doth she think to fool
My King with fi, foh, fum?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The King believes.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Of course my King believes.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: In Catherine.

div.stage: A pause: from off right come distant sounds of laughter, and a flickering glow

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF CHARLES
sp.l: Walk near us in the torch light.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: They are coming.
Madonna, do not let that scornful fire
Die from your face. For such apostasy
There's a divine contempt which makes us strong
To suffer and retaliate. Take heart!
What matters it though this half-minded prince
Goes begging for his crown. — Dost thou not hear me?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Reaching to D'Alençon her two hands
sp.l: To build and build and build on running sands —
How terrible it must be to be God!
Think you I shall be strong enough, my duke?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Oh, I will give more than the world can take,
And fill the gap of this ingratitude
With burning recompense. Lean thou henceforth
On me — on me —

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF CHARLES
sp.l: Enchantress!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: 'Tis my King.
Say I will welcome him within my tent —
And Catherine. This shall be overcome.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: But not alone! Let me stand with thee, Jeanne.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Always you are with me. When I close my eyes,
You lean against a pillar of the dark
And pore upon a book. You do not speak,
And yet I know whom you are reading of —
A certain queen — her name is hard to learn.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Hippolyta!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: A maiden-queen, you said.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: In Attica.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I know not where; good night!
Come not; this good fight will I make alone.

div.stage: With a quick pressure of D'Alençon's hand, exit Jeanne into her tent

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: "Always you are with me." — Did she say those words,
Or am I dizzy with this incense of her?
"Say I will welcome him with Catherine."
What will she do? Well, I can but obey.
"Always you are with me!" Always, always! Here —
On the air, this moonlight, everywhere — her face
Encounters mine in glory.

div.stage: Enter Charles and CATHERINE attended by torch-bearers and followed by La Tremouille , BROTHER RICHARD, and Flavy .]

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: To Catherine, holding her hand and gazing at her
sp.l: Even your shadow
Steals splendour from the moonlight — less a shadow
Than some bright spirit's reflection.

div.stage: He kisses her fingers

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: God! Can that
Which leads him captive be akin to this
Which hallows me with beauty?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Charles is kind
To flatter his old comrade of Chinon.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Chinon! how our life-star hath changed since then!
Aye, Dagobert is dead, and poor King Patch
Is now a prince of Europe, thanks to — thanks
To God's aid and Saint Charlemagne, and now
Henceforth to you, sweet seeress. Tell me, Kate,
Of this white lady in the cloth-of-gold
That comes to you: when did you see her last?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: To-night: her limbs were lovely as first snow,
And with her hand she touched me and said, "Rise,
And seek your King, and go forth in the land,
And let the royal trumpeters ride first
And blow nine blasts before you in each town,
And lo! all buried and concealèd gold
In France shall straight be gathered to your feet
In piles of glory. Give all to your King,
But tell him to beware the town of Rheims,
For if he enters there, my power is spent.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Note that, your Majesty: the town of Rheims!
The vision warns you to turn back from Rheims.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: We'll make this known to Jeanne and change our plans
Accordingly.
She's here?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: There, in her tent
And she hath bade me say —

div.stage: Pauses

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Nothing, sire.

div.stage: Exit swiftly ( right ).]

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: Looking after D'Alençon in surprise, turns to Catherine and the others .]
sp.l: We will go in; you also, gentlemen.

div.stage: As he is about to enter the tent, the tapestry is opened from within by Jeanne, who stands in the entrance

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My Dauphin and the Lady Catherine
Are welcome.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: 'Tis some time, Maid, since we met,
And there are solemn matters to impart.
Come, Catherine.

div.stage: Exit Charles into the tent .]

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.stage: Aside to La Tremouille, as she follows Charles
sp.l: Why do you make me face her!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.stage: Exit Catherine. La Tremouille speaks to Jeanne
sp.l: 'Tis but a moment; play the game well now.
This is Commander Flavy of Compiègne.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I pray you enter, sir.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: This, Brother Richard
Of Troyes.

div.stage: Brother Richard, approaching slow, and suspicious, makes constantly the sign of the cross and scatters before him liquid from a vial

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: What is he sprinkling?

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Holy water.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: More boldly, sir; I shall not fly away.

sp.speaker: BROTHER RICHARD
sp.l: How know I yet whether thou art from God?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Enter and learn. — Come in, Sieur La Tremouille;
The room is small to hold both you and me,
But skilful driver turns in a sharp space.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: 'Tis you or I, Jeanne.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: You or God, Seigneur.

div.stage: They go in together, the tapestry closing behind them. Enter ( right ) D'Alençon and La Hire

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: 'Tis shame enough, La Hire, immortal shame,
That she who hath for us her toil, her visions
Given in service, should be snared about
By webs of this arch-spider, La Tremouille,
To struggle and to suffer; yet 'tis worst
That he — that he, whom from a mockery
She hath made emperor, could so relapse
As to install this heinous substitute,
Rochelle.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Not Catherine? Kate of Chinon!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: She, too, hath visions — in Tremouille's brain —
Impugning those of Jeanne; and Charles, her dupe,
Treats her with amorous credulity,
Half gallant and half gudgeon.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: This would make
The little flowers of Saint Francis swear.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: If they had but devised some common sham!
But to pry inward to her maiden soul
And steal that delicate and fairy stuff
The visionary fabric of a child,
Whose dreams of saint and seraphim take on
The sureness of reality — to make
Of that, I say, a tawdry counterfeit
To ordain the humbug of a courtesan —
No, it is monstrous!

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Peste! less metaphysic,
And say what's to be done. Where is she?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: There;
The King and Catherine are with her.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Well,
Trust her to make a charlatan turn feather.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: There is the pity of it! How may she,
Unconscious child, disprove in Catherine
The nature of illusions which her own
Imagination shares? — God spare her that!
For there's no pang, 'mongst all our mortal hurts,
Sharp as the vivisection of a dream.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: I love thee, friend D'Alençon, but thy mouth
Is stuffed too full of parchment. Pray, disgorge;
What means all this?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l:
No matter.
( Broodingly )
Once at Orleans
I spake harsh truth to her myself. God knows
I said it but to save her.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: By my stick,
What shall we do? Go in there and smash pates?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: That would be madness.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: What the devil, then?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: This: I am strong in money and estates
And have a certain influence with Charles
Which I have never yet used: if he disowns
Jeanne d'Arc, then I will offer her my hand
In marriage.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Thou! thou — to the Maid of God!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: No, to the maid of Domremy — "Jeannette."
This is no time for superstitious cant;
I must now serve her and be practical.
I am a duke and she is peasant-born;
I, as her husband, would uphold her power;
If she reject me — mine alone the pain.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Dost thou not fear the wrath of God for this?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: There is no God for me but human love,
Nor vision save the true vouch of mine eyes,
And human love and true vouch of mine eyes
Compel me to this act.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: How long hast thou
Run daft?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Jeanne! Jeanne! thou shalt not stand alone.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.stage: Hastening after D'Alençon, where he has gone toward Jeanne's pavilion .]
sp.l: Fala! This comes of poesie and parchment!
Look ye, my duke, walk this way to my tent
And reassure me that thou be not mad.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Indeed, for love of her, perhaps I am.

div.stage: Exeunt at back, La Hire drawing D'Alençon away from the tent, from which — after a brief pause — Charles bursts forth, followed by Catherine and soon afterward by La Tremouille, who, standing at the entrance of the tent watching them, twists the tapestry with his fingers .]

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Charles! Charles, my King! Forgive me.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: To forgive
Is simple: to obtain forgiveness — where
'Mongst all my fellow-men may I now look
To be forgiven.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: I am penitent.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Why, so am I; yet surely as that moon
Shall wane, so surely shall we lapse again.
Such creatures, Kate, as you and I are changelings,
Filched out of hell by Satan's forefinger
And smuggled into clouts of human kind
To mock at God the Father.

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: Mine the sin;
I lied to you.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Hush! I lied to myself.
Who made me King of France? Whose vision smote
The clutch of England's armies from my throne? —
Go on! put out those lights, and if you can
Put out those stars! and thou, dear Maid of God,
Let me forget how basely I forgot.

div.stage: Exit with torch-bearers. La Tremouille comes to Catherine, where she stands trembling

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Have we been drugged with wine?
What happened there?
I saw you speak to Jeanne, Jeanne look at you.
What was it she did?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.l: I know not what she did,
But what she is shone through her as a lamp
Into my wretched heart, and made me weep
To know myself. — Pray, lead me to my tent.

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Defeat once more; defeat! By Hercules!
For strategy to outwit the lords of Rome
Commend me to a sheep-girl from Lorraine!

div.stage: Exit with Catherine. Within the tent is heard the voice of Brother Richard

sp.speaker: BROTHER RICHARD
sp.stage: Enter from the tent Louis, who holds aside the tapestry, staggering with sleepiness. As Brother Richard passes out, he pauses and looks back within; then turns, moved, to Louis
sp.l: The city's gates shall open to the King.
Child, thou art hallowèd to be her page.

div.stage: Exit toward the ramparts .]

sp.speaker: LOUIS
sp.l: I dreamt I was awake and marching — marching —

div.stage: Sinking upon the near bench, he is overcome by slumber. Enter Jeanne and Flavy from the tent .]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I promise you, Commander, I will aid
Your brave folk in their need. Bid them take heart!
As soon as I have crowned my King at Rheims,
I will go to help the good town of Compiègne.

sp.speaker: FLAVY
sp.l: Your coming shall be rarely welcomed, Maid.

div.stage: Exit ( right ).]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: All will be over soon — my King be crowned!
Louis, come forth! We'll sleep under the sky;
The night is hot, it stifles there within —
Louis!
Ah, weary boy! Thou art still marching
Toward Rheims. — Wait but a moment, little Louis,
Under our lids I'll overtake thee there.

div.stage: She lies down in her armour on the next bench and falls asleep in the moonlight. Enter at back, D'Alençon and La Hire. Seeing Jeanne, they pause, speaking together in low tones

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Not if thy love were whiter and more chaste
Than Abelard's for his dead Heloise —
No, friend D'Alençon!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Will you answer me?
A thousand common drudges, artisans,
Peasants and townsfolk daily flock to her
And kiss that hand in homage. — Am then I
Less worthy?

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: They have faith in her. They seek
Salvation.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: For themselves! I seek it for her.
This maid is holy by simplicity
And not by miracle. She is a brave
And gentle girl, no more. — How noble she sleeps!
By Heaven, I will keep vigil here to-night.
I love her. Do you trust my honour? — Leave me.

sp.speaker: LA HIRE
sp.l: Good night, friend; but beware the Lord His angels.

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: As he springs to kiss her hand, he is caused to stagger back by a dazzling, intervening splendour, out of which there takes shape the winged form of St. Michael, holding his sword drawn
With his sword St. Michael strikes D'Alençon
sp.l: When did such maidenhood sleep in the moon
Before? Or such a soldier dream in armour?
The camp is silent and this summer night,
But all the dark is sown with dragon's teeth
That with the dawning shall spring up in steel
To rage and stab again. — What martial seed,
Dropt in the April lap of green Lorraine
By angels sacking hell from Sinai's mount,
Bourgeoned this armèd girl to captain us?
Here sleeps in silver the strong virgin — France.
She murmurs: What was that? — Dear God, my name!
"D'Alençon!" — Jeanne! Jeanne, leave thy dreams ajar
And let me through to thee — so, with a kiss.
Thou burnest me, beloved; I grow blind;
My brain is stung with fire. Where are thou snatched
In flame away from me? — Ah! — stand not there
Between us! Merely would I bend to touch
Her still hand with my lips and then begone,
And yet are you implacable? — Stern Saint,
Vision, or flaming Minister of Heaven,
Hallucination, or Apocalypse,
Whatso you are that, beautiful, take on
The likeness of imagination, why —
Why do you stand between us?
Monseigneur!
At last the knowledge and the sin of it,
The sinning and the beauty! — Lord, I go.
For thou art bridegroom to the Maid of God,
And she who lieth there is thy betrothed,
And I, that dared to love, have sinned. Adieu,
Bright sentinel! Thine is the vigil now,
The midnight and the Maid inviolate.

div.stage: Exit D'Alençon among the cypresses. A minute now passes before the curtain falls. Various night sounds steal upon the scene; distant torches flicker out; and the murmurs and motions of a great army, camped, are suggested to the audience's imagination, while Jeanne — the virgin-captain of that host — lies sleeping, moonlit, in her armour, guarded by the sentinel archangel, vigilant-eyed

div.head: SCENE II:
div.stage: A Street in Rheims. July 17, 1429.

The street itself is hidden behind an old, half-ruined wall of the city, over the irregular top of which are visible the upper windows, balconies, and gables of the houses opposite, from which the inmates are seen watching the crowds below, invisible to the audience. The foreground of the scene consists partly of the wall itself, partly of an embankment ( with a crooked, elevated foot-path, conducted by stone steps to different heights ), which slopes upward to the wall's edge. On the left, at a breach in the wall, is a wide ruined gate, admitting ingress from the street on to the lower foreground left where the path starts to ascend the slope of the embankment. Seated on the wall, or peering over it ( where they stand on the embankment foreground ), and filling the gateway, are varicoloured groups of persons. Among these ( right ) are Pierre Cauchon and NICOLAS LOISELEUR, in the dress of artisans; near the gateway, amid a group of peasants, Jacques d'Arc, Perrin, Pierre d'Arc, and Mengette. High in a seat of vantage on the wall, a PRIEST is looked up to by the people near by, as a presiding authority . The following dialogue is spoken — with varying intervals of pantomime — during partial lulls in the hubbub of the hidden populace in the street, and the reflex of that among the groups of the foreground . As the curtain rises, there resound from the left a fanfare and a vast, distant shout .

sp.speaker: A CITIZEN
sp.l: Those trumpets, father?

sp.speaker: THE PRIEST
sp.l: Now the King receives
His crown in the cathedral, and the people
Acclaim the Maid of God.

sp.speaker: PERRIN
sp.l: Why were we late!
They say Jeannette stands next the King himself.

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.l: And all in armour!

sp.speaker: PIERRE
sp.l: If she goes right by!
And if she never sees us!

sp.speaker: JACQUES D'ARC
sp.l: Fret thee not;
I ha' fetched from home a clinkle in my pouch
To catch thy sister's ear.

sp.speaker: PIERRE AND MENGETTE
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Look!

div.stage: Shows a string of little pewter sheep bells

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: Your Reverence' disguise is masterly.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Thanks, Nicolas; and yours!

sp.speaker: A WOMAN
sp.l: From Domremy?
Aye, that's the town the King hath freed from tax
Because the Maid would ask no other boon.

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.stage: Anticipating her triumphant effect with blushes of pleasure
sp.l: I am her neighbour and her brother's wife!

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Yes, much at stake! My kind friend Winchester
Hath promised me the archbishopric of Rouen —
When she is ashes.

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: That should not be long.
She goes hence to help Flavy at Compiègne.
At Compiègne there will be a witch for sale.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Aye, Flavy knows the smell of English gold —
How proud her pageant rides! The dust rolls up
Like smoke before her.

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: Soon it shall be fire .

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Look where she comes!

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: Who looketh where she goes?

div.stage: The pageant has begun to enter. Above the wall are visible the lances and halberds of the marching soldiers, their standards and the floats of the pageant. From the left, after the passing of several displays and devices, the tumult and hosannahs roar and swell to a rhythmic, pæan-like acclaim upon the entrance ( as yet unseen by the audience ) of Charles and Jeanne .]

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.l: Noël! Noël! Noël! The Maid of God!

div.stage: As this royal portion of the pageant passes beneath the central groups in the foreground, Jacques d'Arc at the gateway takes from his pouch the little pewter bells, and, raising, tinkles them in the uproar. As he does so, the throng in the breach itself are swayed inward and aside by a commotion from the street without, and Jeanne and the King appear in the gateway on horseback, their immediate followers — La Tremouille, De Chartres, D'Alençon, La Hire — being visible behind them

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My King!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.stage: Halting the procession, turns solicitously to Jeanne who, not yet seeing Jacques d'Arc and his bells, is listening with a bewildered look of pleasure
sp.l: What is it, Maid?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The sheep!

sp.speaker: JACQUES D'ARC
sp.stage: Breaking from the crowd and going to her
sp.l: Jeannette!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Ah! — Papa Jacques!

sp.speaker: PIERRE, MENGETTE, AND PERRIN
sp.l: Jeannette! Jeannette!

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: My lass!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Kissing his hands where he raises them to her
sp.l: And art not angry with me?

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: God is good.
Thou hast served Him long, lass. Come now home with me!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: This is thy father?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: May I go with him?
See, he hath fetched me these from home.
Mengette!
Perrin! — I did not knit the other mitten!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Sire —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: May I go? My vow to God is kept,
And nothing now prevents —

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Your promise, Maid.
Compiègne —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I had forgot!

sp.speaker: LA TREMOUILLE
sp.l: Go on.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: To the group with her father
sp.l: Adieu!
I must go to serve my good friends at Compiègne.

sp.speaker: JACQUES
sp.l: Thy mother! — waiteth for thee.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: Tossing to Jacques the steel gauntlet from her right hand
sp.l: Show her this,
And tell her I would rather spin at home,
But for a web begun God sendeth thread
And I must spin for France.

div.stage: The Procession begins to move; the crowd sways between Jeanne and her father, who stands, with bowed head, holding the gauntlet

sp.speaker: MENGETTE
sp.stage: Lifted from her feet by Pierre, tears off her head-dress and waves it above the peopled heads
sp.l: Jeannette!

div.stage: Jeanne, turning her horse and looking straight on, holds in her left hand her banner; in her right — close to her ear — the string of clinking bells, to the others inaudible through the cries of "Noël!" and the thunder of the cathedral chimes

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: The sheep!

div.head: ACT V
div.stage: SCENE: Jeanne's Prison at Rouen. May 30, 1431.

A dim room, with only one small, barred window ( at back ) very high up. Doors, right ( down stage ) and left ( up stage ). Massive stone pillars sustain the ceiling. Inconspicuous in the obscurity of the right upper corner stands a narrow cage, with irons for the occupant's neck and hands . As the scene opens, a group of persons in black ecclesiastical gowns is seen passing slowly across the prison chamber, from the door of an inner room ( right ) to the outer door ( left ). Among them are Pierre Cauchon and Nicolas Loiseleur. They are followed by John Gris , BROTHER MARTIN LADVENU, and the CAPTAIN OF THE ENGLISH GUARD. In the background loiter THREE SOLDIERS OF THE GUARD, coarse types of men-at-arms .

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: What think you, Nicolas?

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: Her spirit fails;
I fear she will not last.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: That will not do!
She cost too dear a penny at Compiègne
For us to let her now escape the fire
And pass like any Christian soul.

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: 'Twere pity.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: And this long trial which hath lately closed
To end in farce! — Besides, the folk of Rouen,
That weep around this prison on their knees,
Will say we murdered her. Whereas, i' the fire,
Not merely shall we brand her heretic
And witch, but we shall tarnish with her shame
The crown of Charles, which this said witch put on him.

sp.speaker: LOISELEUR
sp.l: Then, too, your Reverence' archbishopric
So nearly earned!

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Hush; nothing of that now.
We must make haste. — Captain, a word with you.

div.stage: As Cauchon takes the Captain of the Guard aside, John Gris speaks to Brother Martin

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: I was her prisoner at Orleans once,
And now her keeper! Would to God again
I were her prisoner, and she once more
In that proud freedom. — When did she begin
To doubt her Voices?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: After the great lapse,
When she recanted all in the open square,
Seeing the executioner's black cart
Awaiting her. Since then, though she hath now
Resumed her man's garb which she then put off,
And docilely affirms her faith, yet she
Is shaken in her soul, for now no more
She sees her visions, hears no more her Voices.

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: To what doth she ascribe this?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: I know not.
A year of darkness and imprisonment,
And slow, sharp probings of the Inquisition
Have weighed on her bold spirit. This I know:
That many an age your English hearts shall bleed
To hear the story which doth end this hour.

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: Where stays your Paris monk?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: The duke is still here;
Three days I have concealed him in my cell,
But still have found no means to bring him to her.

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: Means must be found. I'll call the guard away.

sp.speaker: CAUCHON
sp.l: Thou, Brother Martin, come with us; let stole
And Eucharist be brought for her last rites.
You have your orders, sir.
Come, gentle masters,
This noon we'll lunch with long-earned appetites.

div.stage: Exeunt ( left ) Cauchon, Loiseleur, Brother Martin, and the Doctors of the Inquisition. At the door, John Gris stops and speaks to the Captain of the Guard

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: The orders of my lord the Bishop you
Will execute with gentleness. Remember
That you are Englishmen and she a maid.

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
sp.l: Remember, too, my lads, how this same "Maid"
By damnèd arts hath sent ten thousand souls
Of Englishmen to hell.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Comes now her turn.

sp.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
sp.l: Fetch here the prisoner and put on her
The garb of heresy.

div.stage: Exeunt guards into the inner room, whence they return immediately, dragging Jeanne, one of whose feet is tied to a heavy log. From this they unchain her. She is dressed still as a man, in a worn, dull-coloured garb. In aspect she is very pale, and of a spiritual emaciation. From the cage in the corner, the Captain has brought a long white tunic and a mitre-shaped cap, which he hands to one of the guards, who prepares to put them upon Jeanne

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Will it be now?

sp.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
sp.l: Aye, and forever after.

sp.speaker: SECOND GUARD
sp.l: There be piled
Kindlings in Rouen Square. After the Bishop
Hath spoke his sermon, there shall be a bonfire.

sp.speaker: THIRD GUARD
sp.l: They say the Square is packed.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Come!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: 'Tis for me?
What are these, sir?

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: The wedding cap and gown
That old Dame Inquisition gives her daughters
When they go to the Devil.

sp.speaker: SECOND GUARD
sp.l: He'll make her a brave
House-warming —
Hail to 's doxy!

sp.speaker: THIRD GUARD
sp.l: Hail her cap!

div.stage: Taking it from her head, for Jeanne to see, he holds it aloft while the other guards, severally bowing and doffing before it, read the words which are blazoned on its surface

sp.speaker: THE GUARDS
sp.l: Apostate! — Heretic! — Idolatress!

div.stage: Reënter Brother Martin, with candles and stole. He stands in the doorway; behind him appears another cowled figure, which withdraws when the Captain speaks

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: I bring the last rites for the prisoner.

sp.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
sp.l: Whom hast thou with thee there?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: A monk from Paris.

div.stage: Enter abruptly, in the doorway, John Gris

sp.speaker: GRIS
sp.l: Captain, your guard is wanted in the court!

sp.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
sp.l: Come! — Jeanne, by order of my lord the Bishop,
Thou hast four minutes wherein to confess
And gear thy soul whither it goes. — Hear'st thou?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I hear thee, godon .

sp.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
sp.l: The executioner
Is waiting in the court. When you shall hear
His bell-cart tolling, come away.

div.stage: Exeunt the Captain, John Gris, and the guards, the third guard handing the mitre-cap to Brother Martin, who sets it and the candles on the floor of the cell. During the time in which the door remains open, sounds of distant chanting come from without

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: What voices
Are those?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: Priests chanting for thy soul. — My child,
I will return at once and bring thee comfort.

div.stage: Exit ( left ).]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: They are not priests: that is the Judge's Clerk
Reading the questions in the Justice Hall;
Day after day they lead me down to answer.
Do not you hear? Those are the accusations,
And there are seventy. He's crying them
Aloud in the open court. He will not cease;
And all the masters' gowns are turned to grey. —
Cease! I have heard all, my lords! Pray, bid him cease.

div.stage: From behind the blank wall which Jeanne, clad in her white tunic, thus supplicates with outstretched arms, there rises, articulate, out of the far-heard chanting of the monks, and becomes loud enough for clearness — a monotonous, droning voice

sp.speaker: THE VOICE
sp.p: And first, according to Divine Law, as according to Canon and Civil Law, it is to you the Bishop, as Judge Ordinary, and to you the Deputy, as Inquisitor of the Faith, that it appertaineth to drive away, destroy, and cut out from the roots in your Diocese, and in all the kingdom of France, heresies, witchcrafts, superstitions; to punish and amend all those who act against our Faith: to wit, sorcerers, diviners, invokers of demons, their abettors and accomplices. And your power as to this exists against all lay persons, whatever be their estate, sex, quality, and preëminence; in regard to all you are competent judges.
What have you to say to this Article?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Pass on!

div.stage: The Voice resumes with the same intoning monotony. Before it is done speaking, there softly reënters ( left ) Brother Martin, followed by D'Alençon. The latter is dressed in a robe and cowl similar to the monk's, but these are but thrown loosely over his usual garb. Jeanne neither hears nor sees them

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF THE CLERK
sp.p:
But it is time to instruct you more fully, my lords and judges, on the offences, excesses, crimes, and misdemeanours committed by the accused, Jeanne d'Arc, in many and diverse places. In her childhood she was not instructed in the beliefs and principles of our Faith; but by certain old women she was initiated in the science of witchcraft, divination, superstitious
doings, and magical arts — so much so that, in these interrogations before you, touching her visions and the apparitions of fairies, she hath confessed that even now she doth not know if these fairies were evil spirits or not.
What have you to say to this Accusation?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: I have answered you before. As for the fairies,
I know not what they are. But for my teaching
I was brought up to say my Creed, and do
Whatso a good child ought.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Whom speaks she to?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: Some phantom of her fever;
For pale hallucinations come to her,
No more her sacred visions; random voices —
The memories of her late torture-trial —
Not now her saints. Oft, as I told you, she
Will call your name.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Oh, that she call it now!

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF THE CLERK
sp.p:
Of Robert de Baudricourt Jeanne asked to have made for her a man's dress and armour appropriate. These garments and armour being furnished, Jeanne, rejecting and abandoning women's clothing, her hair cut around like a young coxcomb, took tunic, doublet,
surcoat, close-cut cap, buskins, spurs, sword, lance, and other arms in fashion of a man, affirming that in this she was executing the order of God as had been prescribed to her by God's messenger.

div.stage: Jeanne makes toward the wall a gesture of pathetic affirmation

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Surely she hears some voice! — Is she so ill?

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF THE CLERK
sp.p: What have you to say to this Accusation?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Pass on! It is so.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Jeanne! What is so?

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: She wanders.
Speak to her; but remember you yourself
Are under doom — an escaped prisoner;
Speak not too loud.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Nay, let them find me. Death
Comes equitably now with her; and though
I am powerless to save her, yet 'tis sweet
Not to survive.

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: Your will, then, is to be
Discovered and to perish?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: If I
Consent, it is because she needs you: you,
Who first instilled her doubts, must extirpate them.
Farewell; though she shall think you but a dream,
Yet speak! — I will confess her — at the flames.

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The flames! — O Christ! how dare I speak to her?

div.stage: Leaning faintly against one of the stone pillars, D'Alençon struggles for self-possession

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF THE CLERK
sp.p: Obstinate in her presumption, Jeanne hath said, proclaimed, and published that she recognized and discerned the voices of Archangels, Angels, and Saints; and she hath affirmed that she knoweth how to distinguish their voices as of such; she hath not feared to proclaim that St. Michael, Archangel of God, did himself come to her; also that by revelation of Saints the crown of Charles the King was shown to him through her. All these are lies imagined by Jeanne at the instigation of the Devil, or suggested by demons in deceitful apparitions, to make sport of her curiosity — she who would search secrets beyond her capacity and condition.
What have you to say to this Accusation?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: What should I say, my lords? — Yes, they were lies!
My Voices lied to me, my friendly visions,
That brought to me all holy signs of heaven,
They lied — they lied! for look, my masters: now —
Now I am brought before you in this hall,
And you command me to reveal you proofs
That what I saw was holy; now I call
On those bright saints to be my witnesses —
They come not, answer not! Ah, truly ye
Condemn me; I was tempted: demons were they,
And have deserted me, deluded me.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Do not believe them, Jeanne!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: You hear him, judges.
Even so he spake at Orleans, and I chid him.
My duke forewarned me well, yet I believed.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Child, look on me. The latest moment, Jeanne,
Yet I am here: I too was prisoner,
Knew naught of this; but when I heard, escaped,
And now I am come to witness to the truth.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My lords, you hear! Even he is come, a witness,
Before you.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Not a witness before them, —
Your dread, grey judges, — but before those saints
And thy dear soul to attest their faith in you
And yours in them.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: How pale thou art, my friend.
You must not sorrow now to speak against me.
You bade me doubt those visions, yet I kept
My faith; the blame was mine. Well I remember
You warned me then they were but "vanities
And whisperings of the air."

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: I knew not then —

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: How France should sell me to the English! No!
Pass on; 'tis over. — Will you address the court?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Here is no court nor trial-chamber, Jeanne.
Feel here — D'Alençon's hand; this is your prison,
Where in a little moment Death shall enter
And lead us both away. I cannot bar
His coming, child, but I can make it happy
If this swift prayer can move your soul to hear.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: In the distance a harsh tolling resounds, and ceases
sp.l: To me you pray? To me? — They used to pray
To me at Rheims, and all the chimes were ringing.
Hark! they have begun again.

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: That knelling bids
Me speak, nor hesitate. Jeanne, what I say
Is heaven and hell and life and death: I love you,
How — you shall know and understand. At first
I, now your anchorite, burned high for you
With man's desire. Ere yet you came to France,
I caught afar the pastoral breath of you,
And sudden, when you'd come, you rose for me
Amidst our army's spears — a martial Ruth,
Bright from those rustled battle-sheaves of men,
And drew me, soul-bound. — 'I will love this child,'
I vowed, 'and win her love, for 'tis in sooth
A simple child, whose quick, religious heart
And pied imagination fill for her
The air with painted angels, speaking saints
And bell-toned voices. Who that lives would not
Follow her eyes to Orleans and to Rheims?'
And so, a pagan in your holy war,
I followed you. At last we camped by Troyes.
There in the moon, after the weary day,
While pale in armour you lay slumbering,
I kept my vigil. Suddenly, your lips
Murmured "D'Alençon." Ah! I leapt to kiss
Your sleeping hand — Jeanne! Jeanne! it rose between us
And smote me back!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: My hand?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: No, his .

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: What smote thee?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: The mystery of you, the holiness,
For these — a blazing, keen, and two-edged sword —
That silent angel, radiant in wrath,
Did smite me with; and lo! with blinded eyes
I saw thee — what thou art: the Maid of God.
Angel, or saint, or guardian wraith — that blow
Made me to pray, to tremble, and believe.
I, who did boast to riddle a child's heart,
Was humbled and was glad.

div.stage: The knelling resounds again .]

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Is it the cart?
I am afraid. Art thou to go with me?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Of course; and all your visions wait for you
To call them. Child, let not my sceptic love
Lead your weak spirit to the world's dark sill
Thus stricken — blinded, groping for its saints
Believe! you who have made me to believe.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Why have they then forsook me — those sweet saints
That used to come — at least, methought they came.
Why do I not behold them any more?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Because — remember what you told the King!
You must believe before you may behold!
But I — I wronged your faith. Those noxious seeds
Of doubt I sowed in freedom — here, in darkness,
Prison, and pain, your black Inquisitors
Have fostered for their ends. They are your demons,
That have deluded you with sophistries;
And if they ask for proof, say to them this:
Orleans is not a lie; the gates of Troyes
Are not delusions; no! Rheims stands in stone;
France — France is saved, and Charles the King is crowned!
Who hath done this but God and Jeanne, His Maid?

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: Art thou a dream comest to tell me this?
Or art my knight — my bonny duke?

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.l: Madonna!

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.l: It doth not matter! — Though a thousand miles,
And clouds and towers and darkness are between us,
Still are you with me, absent, like a star.
Thou only knewest me, thou only knowest,
Save God, and thou hast brought me back to Him.
Look down, St. Michael! Once again I wear
Thine armour: Lord, I dread no more the flames.
Lean down, St. Catherine, St. Margaret!
See, now I am your true girl — take my soul
And tell me you forgive, for I believe;
Tell me you are true, and all my sin a dream!

div.stage: Outside as the slow, harsh knelling resounds close by, high in the dim, barred window appear, in splendour, the faces ( and, in part, the forms ) of St. Michael, St. Catherine, and St. Margaret, who look down upon Jeanne

sp.speaker: THE FEMALE SAINTS
sp.l: Thy pain — it is a dream.

sp.speaker: JEANNE
sp.stage: With a cry of passionate joy .]
sp.l: My duke — they hear!
Behold they are come again! I see their faces,
I hear their voices!

sp.speaker: D'ALENÇON
sp.stage: Kneeling beside her with bowed head, kissing the edge of her white robe, speaks to himself
sp.l: Would to God might I!

div.stage: The door ( left ) is thrown open. In the passageway are heard heavy approaching footsteps and a murmur as of many people. Jeanne, standing, gazes up at the grated window — her face lit with a lost rapture

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF BROTHER MARTIN
sp.l: The executioner.

sp.speaker: ST. MICHAEL
sp.stage: His voice sounding with the approaching bell
sp.l: Be not afraid.

div.stage: Away on the left, voices of men are heard chanting: "Kyrie eleison! Christe eleison!"

back.p: FINIS ADDENDA In Act I, the refrain of the opening song is dialectical. In Act III, the letter dictated by Jeanne to the English is authentic; in the same act, the hymn, Veni, Creator Spiritus , known as the Hymn of Charlemagne, was historically sung by Jeanne and the French before battle. In Act V, the words spoken by the Voice of the Clerk are transcribed directly from the translation of the Seventy Articles, prepared by the Promoter d'Estivet, which formed the Accusation of Jeanne's Trial in Ordinary — published in the Appendix of the volume of Original Documents on Jeanne d' Arc, edited by T. Douglas Murray, New York, McClure, Phillips, &.mp; Co., 1902. The author's sincere acknowledgments are due to Mrs. Patrick Campbell for her friendly interest in having specifically directed his attention to the above illuminating book, which has constituted the chief informing source, and a large inspiration, to his work. The music of the play — incidental, as well as lyrical — has been composed by Mr. F. S. Converse, and may be had in published form. The cover design and the scene illustrations of the present volume were drawn by Mr. Barry Faulkner. The acting rights of the play, in America and England, are owned by Mr. E. H. Sothern and Miss Julia Marlowe. PERCY MACKAYE. CORNISH, N.H. September, 1906.
